PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President of the Senate and Senators in Parliament assembled:

The Hawke Labor Government's Privacy Amendment Bill concerning credit reference reporting will-

CRIMES (SUPERANNUATION BENEFITS) BILL 1989

Much has been made in recent years of the impact of corruption on many facets of Australian society. The Commission of inquiry into possible illegal activities and associated police misconduct conducted by Mr Tony Fitzgerald QC constitutes one of the most prominent and comprehensive enquiries on the subject. The Bills now before the Parliament represent a strong weapon against potential corruption. Unlike the Queensland legislation which was presumably passed, in response to revelations before the Commission, the Crimes (Superannuation Benefits) Bill covers not only public officials and judges but also parliamentarians. It supplements measures passed by the Parliament during the autumn sittings dealing with corrupt members of the Australian Federal Police.

In accordance with comments the Attorney-General made to the House of Representatives when he introduced the Australian Federal Police Legislation Amendment Bill 1989, these bills will provide for the restraint of property and the recovery of superannuation benefits which have already been paid to a corrupt employee who is convicted and sentenced to more than 12 months imprisonment.

The Crimes (Superannuation Benefits) Bill 1989 provides for the loss, or recovery, of government funded superannuation benefits payable, or paid, to existing or former employees of the Commonwealth or of a Commonwealth Authority who are convicted of a corruption offence and sentenced to imprisonment for life or for more than 12 months. These provisions do not, of course, affect the payment of the employee's own contributions and any interest on those contributions that may have accrued under a superannuation scheme.

The bill empowers a court, upon the application of the director of public prosecutions, when sentencing the person for a corruption offence to make a superannuation order. These orders provide that any future payments of government monies in respect of the person must cease and may, where appropriate, specify an amount that is to be recovered from a person who has already received payment of benefits as with the Proceeds of Crime Act 1987, the amount specified in the order may be recovered as if it were a debt and, as under that Act, there are sophisticated measures to ensure that payment is not avoided by the use of the corporate veil, unlawful disposal of property or by absconding.

The bill has a comprehensive regime of restraining orders which enables property of a person who is convicted, charged or about to be charged with a corruption offence, to be frozen until the results of the criminal proceedings and any application for a superannuation order are known.

As under the Bankruptcy Act 1966, any property that has been disposed of by the person by way of gift can also be there subject of restraining orders. These provisions are designed to combat efforts by the offender to dispose of property by giving it to relatives or associates as soon as detection of the offence appears likely.

The government has rejected the approach taken by the Queensland Parliament in the Public Officers Superannuation Benefits Recovery Act 1988 whereby the courts are given the option of forfeiting only part of the person's superannuation entitlement where the offence is considered to be minor or where hardship may result from the order. Rather, minor offences are placed outside the scope of the Commonwealth Bill by the condition precedent that a sentence of more than 12 months imprisonment be imposed for the offence.

This government is firmly of the view that there is no scope for watering down the forfeiture in such cases as superannuation benefits should only be paid from public monies to persons who discharge their duties in a non-corrupt manner. The government views corruption of office as a failure to fulfil a condition of employment which should result in the disentitlement to publicly funded superannuation benefits. While the consequence of conviction for a corruption offence under the bill will be the loss of publicly funded superannuation benefits there may also be other remedies available under other legislation. For example, where a corruption offence involved the payment of a bribe to a public official, an amount equal to the bribe may be recoverable under the Proceeds of Crime Act 1987.

This government is determined to ensure that corruption does not infiltrate the commonwealth or its instrumentalities and this bill will provide a strong financial disincentive to any who may be tempted to engage in corruption now or in the future.
I commend the bill to the Senate.
AUSTRALIAN FEDERAL POLICE AMENDMENT BILL 1989

This Bill is a companion Bill to the Crimes (Superannuation Benefits) Bill 1989 and strengthens the provisions of the Australian Federal Police Legislation Amendment Act 1989 which was passed during the Autumn sittings of Parliament. The Bill contains provisions which facilitate the recovery of Commonwealth funded superannuation benefits already paid to corrupt members of the AFP and enable the Director of Public Prosecutions to obtain restraining orders against property to secure such recovery where it is likely that a person may be convicted of a corruption offence.
The Scheme is broadly similar to that contained in the Crimes (Superannuation Benefits) Bill 1989.
These measures were foreshadowed in the House of Representatives during the debate on the Australian Federal Police Legislation Amendment Bill 1989 in May this year.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.

I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

The proposed amendment to delete reference to the Chief Justice as an ex-officio member of the National Debt Commission has been introduced in deference to the wishes of the Chief Justice of Australia, Sir Anthony Mason.

The Chief Justice requested the amendment on the grounds that the activities of the Commission have no relationship to the responsibilities of the Chief Justice, and that a Chief Justice is ordinarily unable to contribute any economic expertise to the Commission's deliberations.

The National Debt Commission was established under the National Debt Sinking Fund Act 1923. The Chief Justice's membership was based on British precedence and on the belief that public confidence in the Commission would be enhanced by the presence of an important apolitical figure.

Neither reason is relevant today, and there is no particular need for the Chief Justice's membership as a legal representative. Legal matters affecting the National Debt Commission and the National Debt Sinking Fund are referred to the Attorney-General's Department which is represented on the Commission by its Secretary.
The legislation has no financial implications.
I commend this Bill to the Senate.

COMMONWEALTH BORROWING LEVY AMENDMENT BILL 1989

The purpose of this Bill is to provide for certain technical amendments which will ensure that the Commonwealth Borrowing Levy continues to apply to all Commonwealth authorities and their subsidiaries, as was intended by the Commonwealth Borrowing Levy Act 1987.

The levy is imposed on the borrowings of all Commonwealth semi-government authorities and Government-owned companies, other than those engaged in the business of financial intermediation, such as the Commonwealth Bank and the Australian Industry Development Corporation. The levy currently set at a rate of 0.125 per cent per annum, is designed to take account of the benefit these enterprises receive in terms of access to financial markets by virtue of their Commonwealth ownership. By ensuring that the effective cost of borrowings to these enterprises is more directly comparable with that faced by private sector borrowers, the enterprises are encouraged to take full account of the cost to the community of their investment decisions.

The amendments provided for all in the Bill will expand the list of authorities subject to the levy to include the Civil Aviation Authority and Aerospace Technologies of Australia, two recently-created Commonwealth authorities. The Bill also provides for the ACT Electricity and Water Authority to be excluded from paying the levy from 11 May 1989, the day ACT self-government was proclaimed. This will ensure that, under the Commonwealth Borrowing Levy Act 1987, ACT authorities will be treated on the same basis as State and Northern Territory semi-government authorities.

The Bill also provides for some minor definitional changes which will allow the levy to be applied to any new authorities through their enabling legislation, and to the subsidiaries of Commonwealth authorities. This will minimise the need for further legislative changes of this nature.
These amendments will increase revenue raised from the levy in the 1989-90 financial year by an estimated $220,000 to $8,720,000.
I present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill, and commend the Bill to the Senate.
COMMONWEALTH BORROWING LEVY COLLECTION AMENDMENT BILL 1989

The Commonwealth Borrowing Levy Amendment Bill 1989 provides that, from the proclamation of ACT Self-government on 11 May 1989, borrowings by the ACT Electricity and Water Authority (ACTEW) cease to be subject to the Commonwealth Borrowing Levy.

The purpose of this Bill is to provide that the ACTEW also cease to be liable for payments of the former Commonwealth Guarantee Charge. Under the current legislation, the ACTEW is liable for the charge in respect of outstanding amounts of borrowings undertaken in 1986-87.
This Bill will reduce the revenue raised from the Charge in 1989-90 by an estimated $54,000 to $2,446,000.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.

DEBATE.TITLE: SUPERANNUATION AND OTHER BENEFITS LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1989

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 5 October, on motion by Senator Walsh:

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K. .

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak to the Superannuation and Other Benefits Legislation Amendment Bill in the light of the comments by Senator Robert Ray dealing with the additional week we are proposing to sit. Senator Ray cited this piece of legislation as one of the reasons that we have to have extra sitting time; to enable the 2 per cent increase to be paid the Bill has to go through fairly speedily. Let me say right from the outset that the Opposition is supporting this Bill. It is about time that that 2 per cent was restored. Indeed, in the interests of ensuring that the time of the Senate is not wasted, both Senator Newman and I will be speaking for a period considerably less than people tend to do in this chamber to put the message that we support the legislation, that it is about time the 2 per cent was restored, and that the Government deserves criticism for taking it away in the first place.

SPEECH.PARA: The Bill restores the 2 per cent that was taken away in 1986. At the time the Government used the rationale that, in the interests of everybody being subject to wages restraint, retired public servants under the Commonwealth superannuation scheme and, indeed, veterans would have to suffer a reduction in the annual increase they would normally have expected in accordance with the consumer price index (CPI). In 1986 the CPI was 9.2 per cent but they received a rise of only 7.2 per cent. That was done in a fairly tortuous way. First of all the 9.2 per cent was to be paid. Then it was to be reduced as from 10 October 1986. So those two groups of people suffered a 2 per cent reduction in superannuation payments. The Government said it was always intended that the 2 per cent be restored some time, I think it said, when the economy could afford it. I am pleased to see that it can honour its intent and restore it at this stage. But to say that the economy is in good shape and that is why it is able to so do is really not a credible statement.

Australia is in an all time crisis with its balance of payments, with high inflation and a mismanaged economy. In the port of Sydney a levy of $200 per container is to be levied because of the delays, because of union action and because of the work practices that still exist in that area. Yet the Government is not prepared to tackle that, either. It was mismanagement that caused superannuants to receive the 2 per cent cut in the first place. The same mismanagement is still in place but at least these people will not continue to be made to suffer for the Government's inept handling of the economy. The Opposition welcomes the restoration and supports this Bill.

Before the 1983 election the then shadow Minister for defence, Mr Gordon Scholes, said that there would be no change affecting the defence forces superannuation entitlements. Again, that was not adhered to and those people suffered that cut in 1986. The interference with the integrity of the Commonwealth superannuation scheme has contributed to the erosion of public sector morale, both in the Public Service and in the defence forces. Morale in the Public Service is certainly low. The so-called reforms that the Government introduced have not been successful in increasing morale, or efficiency and accountability in the Public Service. The Government enforced a system on people. Minister Morris said recently that to fix some of those problems he would throw in $10m but he does not know how that $10m is yet to be spent.

Commonwealth superannuants made contributions to the scheme in the belief that there would be a full adjustment of the pension in accordance with the CPI. The peremptory action of the Government in 1986 was in breach of conditions which superannuants believed existed when they made those contributions. The monetary loss that they have suffered during the period 1986 to date will not be restored. They have simply had to suffer that loss but then the standard of living of other Australians has similarly dropped because of the Government's poor management of the economy.

One could be tempted to say-and probably believe-that the restoration of the 2 per cent is being made now because we are going into an election phase, whether the election is to be held on 2 December or whether it is to be held in February. The election has to be held by 12 May. The likelihood is that all the Government's actions-whether it is buying off Kodak (Australasia) Pty Ltd for $60m, the banks for $200m or the airlines for $100m-are taking place in an attempt to get back into the community's good books. The same can be said for the defence forces and the Public Service with the restoration of the 2 per cent which the Government took away in such an arbitrary fashion.

The cynicism of this Government and the way it is breaking down in trying to buy sectional interests are apparent at every phase of its administration. It has only been the constant pressure by the Opposition and others who have been affected that has highlighted this issue as one which the Government, if it were not for its election timetable, would not have acceded to at this point.

I said from the beginning that we support this legislation. I said that it is time that the 2 per cent was restored. I also said that it is important that the Senate and the Australian public understand that the manner in which this is being restored is simply to try to win back a sectional vote from part of the electorate. The incident involving the gentleman in Whyalla in South Australia, who was referred to in such derogatory terms as a `silly old bugger' by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), highlights the attitude which the Government had towards superannuants in 1986. Just as the Prime Minister realised that he had made a grave error and tried to stop the piece of television footage on the Whyalla incident going to air, he is trying to win back the support of people whom he held in contempt in 1986.

It is the responsibility of the Government to provide a sound economy in which Australians can expect to work and to receive benefits in return for the effort that they put in. It is the responsibility of the Government to provide a framework in which the private sector can flourish, in which the public sector is able to perform well and be rewarded and recognised for the good work it does, and to provide a climate in which accountability and efficiency in government are the key words.

The Government, through many actions, has shown that it is cynical, tired and collapsing. As I have said, it is not only trying to buy back this group of people by restoring their rights-their 2 per cent-but it is also trying to buy off other sections such as Kodak, the banks and the airlines. But nothing is being done about the waterfront where the economy is suffering gravely, where there is a grave need for attention, because that is where the union mates still have their clout. The Australian Council of Trade Unions simply will not say that the Government may act in any way to allow those reforms to make our waterfront an efficient part of our export system which, in turn, could assist our economy. The Opposition firmly supports this Bill but, as I have said, it has come too late and it is only part of a `buying back the electors' principle.

When foreign debt as a proportion of GDP is clearly on a falling trend and real wages are on a rising trend the Government will consider the issue.

We saw that, in terms of replacement levels, for every 1,000 Australians to die, only 881 were born last year. We are 12 per cent below the long-term replacement level. One of the reasons given for this by an officer of the Institute of Family Studies was economic. People cannot afford to have children. One economic reason is the inability of the Government to grasp the situation of people attempting to live and raise children in this economic climate where wages are being cut. That is admitted by all. Wages have been cut and the Government's taxation system is bleeding to death families with dependent children.

The taxation system in this country does not even acknowledge that there should be a difference in the taxation mode in respect of an income if that income sustains only one person or ten. I know what I am talking about when I speak about having to sustain a very substantial number of people on one income. I certainly know it from the complaints that I receive from one-income families in the electorate. My concern, as I expressed it in 1986, was that because we have the total wage very often of late the decisions that have been made by industrial tribunals have been made on a percentage basis. Therefore those with higher salaries, when the increase is applied as a percentage of those salaries, get a far greater increase than those at the lower end of the scale. For those on the lower end of the scale a 2 per cent reduction compared with the inflation rate means quite a substantial drop in purchasing power relative to others.

I believe that the Government must look at this situation. There is no equity. This Government is not about equity. There is absolute discrimination against families with dependent children. There is no horizontal tax equity. That is the area I am talking about. The Government says that it can restore the 2 per cent for superannuants. That is good but the reason the Government says it can restore this is because of the economic climate. Is it because of the economic climate or is it because of the political climate? If it is because of the economic climate, the Government should do it for workers too. It should go to the Australian Industrial Relations Commission and stop this nonsense of trying to knock an amount off workers so that their wages do not keep up with inflation. If that is the situation let the Government go next into the Industrial Relations Commission and support an increase which will give the workers of this country an increase so that their wage rates will keep pace with inflation. I believe that I am consistent in saying this, as I pointed it out in September 1986.

I acknowledge and support the Government in restoring this 2 per cent. I voted against it being taken away in 1986. The Government should acknowledge that it is now in a position of going back on the reason that it gave for the reduction of 2 per cent in the first place. Now it appears that workers are the ones that need to be considered as well as the superannuants.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I start by reminding the Committee that the Opposition has considerable objections to the second reading of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission Bill 1989, against which we voted, and the third reading, against which we will vote. Nevertheless, the Senate having agreed to give the Bill a second reading the Opposition, in committee, is doing what it can to overcome some of the worst failures and failings in the Bill. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (65) Page 39, paragraph 89 (4)(b), line 22, after ``Minister,'' insert ``made after consulting the Australian Electoral Commission,''.
This amendment means that a portion of clause 89 will now read as follows:
an estimate by the Minister made after consulting the Australian Electoral Commission, in relation to each region whose boundaries are changed . . .

The Minister for Justice (Senator Tate) has previously indicated to the Committee that the Government finds this amendment acceptable. Therefore, I will not speak to it any further but commend it to the Committee.
Amendment agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (66) ``Page 51, sub-clause 120 (2), definition of ``sufficient number'', line 26, leave out ``25%'', insert ``75%''.

This amendment seeks to leave out the figure 25 per cent, which the Government has defined as being a sufficient number, and insert the figure 75 per cent. This amendment raises a number of issues for consideration by the Committee.

First of all, the purpose of this clause, which relates to the removal of a regional council, is to allow the Minister-although not require the Minister-to remove a council from office and put in an administrator if he receives a petition from 25 per cent of the eligible voters for a region. The figures I have used related to previous regions, and the officers have brought in more recent maps; so some of the figures I will give, although in an indicative sense they are still correct and useful, may be historically dated. Some of the regions are very small, and I can give examples.

Cundeelee, which was previously a region on its own but is no longer, had an eligible voting population of which 25 per cent may have been 48 electors. That situation has been fixed by the Government because it allocated Cundeelee to a different region. For the region of Cook, as it was, 25 per cent of the eligible voters would have been 63 electors, which is a tiny number of people to petition. I will come back and develop the reason why this worries the Opposition. On the other hand, the region of Perth would have required 1,285 electors to sign a petition to trigger this mechanism. The Townsville region would have required 1,561 signatories. The Goulburn region, as it then was, would have required only 113 electors. The trigger mechanism of 25 per cent can be grossly unequal in terms of the number of people who may need to sign a petition. This is partly a consequence of the malapportionment of the regions, which is a matter we discussed previously and which I will not reopen. The Sydney region would require over 2,250 electors to sign a petition before this procedure is triggered. I have taken those figures from the September 1988 map and I acknowledge straightaway that there is a more recent map and there are new regions.

I got these figures from page 1116 and following pages of the transcript of the Senate Select Committee on the Administration of Aboriginal Affairs. I divided those figures to try to give an idea of what the eligible voting population might be. I have made an assessment of the number of children who are not of voting age, and I tried to make an assessment of what would be one-quarter of the potential electors. It would seem that there is a potential, in many regions, for very few people indeed to petition the Minister that he should dismiss a council. What is interesting is that the Minister is not required so to do. The explanatory memorandum makes that quite clear.

TALK.START.PARA: —It says `may', that is correct.

—This is absolutely right. The point I want to make is that the Minister, having received the petition, will then have to satisfy himself that there is just reason to dismiss a regional council. The Minister will have to make the determination himself. All that the trigger mechanism will do will be to require the Minister to look at it; it will still be the Minister's own judgment and decision as to whether a council should be dismissed and an administrator put in. If the Minister thought, for any reason, that a regional council might need to be dismissed, why does he require the petitioning mechanism? Unlike the other petitioning mechanism contained in this Bill, this mechanism does not require the Minister to remove the council.

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition believes that if there is to be a petitioning mechanism, it should be one that will not be subject to mischief. The Opposition is worried about instability. It is worried about the likelihood of factional domination and influences within regional councils. We know that certain kinship groups may be dominant in any region, and it would be fairly simple, under a proportional voting system, to attract 25 per cent of potential electors. Those of us who have had experience with the National Aboriginal Conference (NAC), some of us closer than others, will know just how difficult and important factionalism can be with Aboriginal elected organisations. The factions actually combined to have candidates elected to executive positions on the NAC, and factions within NAC electorates worked to have people elected on a kinship basis. That is a fact of life.

While we are discussing this amendment it is necessary to remind honourable senators that it raises, perhaps for the first time, an issue which we will have to talk about later, and that is the question of whether one should have an electoral roll. This is something that Senator Coulter raised and forced me to think about on the Senate Select Committee. How do we make arrangements in light of the question, 25 per cent of what? Clause 4 defines `electorate number' at page 4 of the Bill in these terms:
. . . `electorate number', . . . means the number of potential voters set out, in relation to the region, in the most recent electorate notice that includes such a number in relation to the region;

The Minister would issue an electorate notice which would identify that in a particular region the number of potential electors was, say, 2,000. Then there might be an election for a regional council in which 300 people might vote. I have chosen the figure of 15 per cent because I can remember history and what the turnouts for the National Aboriginal Conference were. If it is 300, 300 might come together to elect the regional council, but it may then require 500 people to petition for the removal of the regional council. I indicate to my colleagues in the Committee that the question of an electoral roll is one we will have to face sooner or later. I do not think the way in which the Government has proposed to do it is good enough. I was very attracted to Senator Coulter's expressions of concern in the Select Committee about the need for an electoral roll. I think I quote the honourable senator correctly. He was talking about voluntary enrolment but compulsory voting, as occurs in general elections at present. But it is the Opposition's view that we should have a figure higher than 25 per cent. The amendment seeks to insert the figure of 75 per cent. I commend the amendment to clause 120.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government opposes the amendment to clause 120. If I have done my arithmetic correctly, it leads to a rather surprising result. Under the Opposition's proposal, even if 60 or 70 per cent of a regional council's potential voters were upset or even appalled by the distribution of funds, if they were of the view that there has been biased, if not corrupt, suggestions as to how money should be distributed within the various corporations within the regional council's area, because the regional councillors looked after 26 per cent and had them on side they could never get up the petition to dismiss a council, which is the necessary precondition for the Minister's exercise of that power. In other words, if 75 per cent was deemed to constitute a sufficient number, only 26 per cent of the region would need to be kept on side and a petition could not get up even though 60 or 70 per cent of the people might be quite disillusioned and disenchanted and have grave misgivings about the way in which the regional council is operating. That is dangerous and it leads to the very matter which Senator Peter Baume fears-a cultivating of the 26 per cent rather than looking after the greater number of persons within the regional council's jurisdiction. For that reason, it is a somewhat dangerous proposal and the Government opposes the suggestion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Peter Baume is absolutely right when he draws attention to the related difficulties which clause 120 raises. Those difficulties are in relation to who is eligible to vote, how eligibility is to be tested, and from what list of names the Minister will determine whether one has 25, 30, 50, 75 or 100 per cent of the electors. It is certainly an issue that I raised before the Senate Select Committee on the Administration of Aboriginal Affairs. The Committee made certain recommendations in relation to electoral rolls and procedures. The Minister for Justice (Senator Tate) will know that in the succeeding months I have had a number of meetings with the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, Mr Hand, on these related questions. In my view, it is unfortunate that the Minister has not seen fit to move some way towards the adoption of some of these suggestions which the Australian Democrats put to him.

SPEECH.PARA: Again, the Australian Democrats are in a situation in which, on balance, we have to support the legislation or run the risk of its not succeeding. Having said that, I will just run through the preferred position of the Australian Democrats. It would be that we have a better definition of an Aboriginal person which would make it clearer who was eligible and who was not eligible to vote. As Senator Peter Baume pointed out, we would have a system of voluntary registration for voting, but once one's name was on a list of voters and the eligibility had been tested, those people would be required to vote and the sanction in relation to compulsory voting would be determined by the local Aboriginal people. Under those circumstances, it would be quite easy to determine what constituted a given percentage of the electorate. That is our preferred position and for various reasons the Minister has not seen fit to accept our arguments.

I would like to make recommendations in a summing-up speech later in the committee stage in relation to those matters. Coming specifically to the issue of the 25 per cent and 75 per cent arguments, I am minded to accept what the Minister said in relation to the balance between the competing interests of those who may be carrying on some nefarious practice and the interests of the majority of Aboriginal people in a region who may wish to have a regional council withdrawn and replaced by an administrator. The difficulty in this section will arise more in relation to questions of eligibility and a judgment as to who is and who is not eligible and how we determine the percentage, rather than the percentage itself. I lay emphasis on that.

The protections which are built into this clause arise in two ways. Firstly, as Senator Baume pointed out, a petition does not necessarily trigger the dismissal of a regional council. It is still left with the Minister to determine in the light of the petition-which, presumably, will lay out certain matters-whether there is sufficient reason to dismiss a regional council. As Senator Baume sees it, there is a protection at that level in relation to a small number, 25 per cent, ganging up-25 per cent is likely to be more than the percentage of people who actually elected the regional council in many instances; I accept that-and for frivolous or spurious reasons calling for a regional council to be dismissed. The first protection that is built in is that the Minister has an overview on this, can look at the circumstances and arguments raised and say that they do not provide sufficient reason to dismiss a council. It may be argued that perhaps that gives too much power to the Minister when we are on about self-determination and self-management. However, the alternative of demanding a much higher percentage makes it even more difficult for that process to occur. I am not convinced that, in terms of self-management, increasing the percentage to 75 per cent necessarily helps.

The other protection which is built in is a matter which I raised the last time we debated this; that is, that this whole area of election procedures, boundaries and so on will be left to the regional councils to review. Unless Senator Baume is saying that this matter which is now before us being left to the regional councils to review against a legislated 25 per cent requirement is too dangerous, it seems to me that it is in line with the principles of self-determination, self-management, to proceed with it, drawing it to the attention of the regional councils and expecting them to make some representations on this matter after the experience of their first term of office.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition will not call for a division because it does not want to take up the time of the Committee.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (67) Page 33, subclause 70 (3) insert the following subclause:
``(3a) The Commission shall include in each report prepared under subsection (1) the model rules for Regional Council meetings formulated under subsection 125 (12).''.
(68) Page 53, subclause 125 (11), lines 35 and 36, leave out the subclause, insert the following subclauses:

``(11) Subject to subsections (12), (13) and (14), a Regional Council may regulate the conduct of proceedings at its meetings as it thinks fit and, in particular, may conduct its meetings in accordance with Aboriginal or Torres Strait Islander tradition and custom.
``(12) The Commission shall formulate model rules, not inconsistent with this Act, for the conduct of proceedings at meetings of Regional Councils.
``(13) A Regional Council may:
(a) adopt the model rules for the conduct of proceedings at its meetings;
(b) adopt the model rules for the conduct of proceedings at its meetings with such modifications, not inconsistent with this Act, as the Regional Council from time to time determines; or
(c) formulate its own rules, not inconsistent with this Act, for the conduct of proceedings at its meetings.

``(14) Where a Regional Council has not adopted or formulated rules for the conduct of proceedings at its meetings under subsection (13), proceedings at meetings of the Regional Council shall be conducted in accordance with the model rules formulated by the Commission.''.

The present subclause 125 (11) of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commissioner Bill provides that regional councils should be able to regulate their meeting procedures `as they think fit'. This leaves a dangerous gap in providing for the way in which meetings might be conducted. I am reminded of one organisation which asserted that it ran its meetings with a piece of four-by-two. That might be `as people think fit' but it is really not good enough. inevitable disputes arise, it will be enough. For example, when inevitable disputes arise, it will be enough to show that someone `thought fit' to regulate the procedures in a certain way. That really will not be good enough, neither for anyone's protection nor for the reputation of any of the procedures of the regional councils. Some of the councils, especially smaller councils and councils in remote areas, would benefit from the inclusion in the Bill of some guidance on this matter. What is proposed is not unduly onerous or unduly restrictive; it is merely indicative of the kinds of procedures which might be desirable.

More importantly, the existence of model rules is helpful. It provides a fall-back reference point for councils whose resources may be limited and it provides a fall-back reference point when disputes arise, as they inevitably will. For that reason, the Opposition has moved amendments Nos 67 and 68, which amend clause 70 and clause 125, both of them being on the same subject.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government accepts these amendments. The idea of non-compulsory model rules is sensible. One might have anticipated the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission itself issuing them, but for the Parliament to give some basis for that is useful.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendments agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (69) Page 54, clause 127, lines 3 to 22, leave out the clause.

Again, I will not speak unduly at length on this. What is proposed in clause 127 at page 54 of the Bill, which is the subject of this amendment, is really rather an elaborate and bureaucratic concept. It is that delegations may be made from the regional council to certain members of the regional council-in other words, there are capacities to empower certain small groups of people to act with the full authority of the regional council. It is an elaborate and bureaucratic concept for regional councils. Anyway, if councils are not to be incorporated bodies, the formal powers of delegation as set out in clause 127 would seem to be unnecessary.

The idea of delegation to a smaller group is not consistent with the Aboriginal way of doing things. Aboriginal decision-making, as the Minister for Justice (Senator Tate) and Senator Coulter would know, is, in its traditional sense, consensual. In a consensual system, this idea of delegation, giving people authority to act on behalf of the group, may be unnecessary. Further, a capacity for formal delegation would give rise to a situation where a dominant faction could be tempted to seize control of all decision-making by delegating to a smaller group most of the powers and having that smaller group act as a de facto substitute for the regional council. In that way, it could in fact facilitate the concentrating of resources in the hands of a dominant group at the cost of minority or disaffected groups. For those reasons, the Opposition seeks to leave out proposed clause 127 at page 54. I believe that the Government finds that course acceptable.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government accepts the amendment.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not intend to move amendment No. 70 or amendment No. 70a in its amended form. This relates to the question of malapportionment of zone level. We had quite an extensive debate the last time the Committee sat, which was two days ago, about malapportionment within regional councils. I then expressed my disbelief that a Labor government would introduce a Bill with such gross degrees of malapportionment. I indicated that when we came to this matter affecting clause 128 I would test the Australian Democrats by asking them whether they were going to vote for one vote one value. It has been pointed out to me, however, that the consequences of proceeding down this course may not produce all the outcomes which I desire.

SPEECH.PARA: First, I accept the arguments in favour of a separate Torres Strait zone. But by accepting those arguments I am accepting that there is a zone whose population will be smaller; in fact, the region and the zone are the same. I think that Senator Coulter and I would agree that there are reasons for this. My original intention was to seek to create a separate Torres Strait Islander Commission. That at least would have been intellectually consistent, but it would have been an administrative nightmare. So we have not gone down that track. That would have allowed us to address the malapportionment more directly and more consistently.

Secondly, in one of the documents which the officers have tabled, it has been pointed out that there is now shown a Queensland far north and communities zone-I think that is correct-which consists of the regions of Aurukun, Cherbourg, Woorabinda, Doomadgee and Yarrabah-Palm Island. That zone is made up of the deeds of grant in trust communities-the so-called DOGIT communities. We are concerned that, if we persist with this amendment and if we, with the force of logic and oratory, were to carry the day, we might create a situation where this zone would have to be altered in some significant way. We acknowledge that the Government has gone down the right track in creating this particular zone. Because there may be unintended consequences if we pursued proposed amendment 70 to clause 128, the Opposition does not intend to proceed with it. We will let the matter pass.

I repeat that I will be looking closely at the way in which this Bill operates. We still think it is dreadful legislation, but we will be looking to see the extent of malapportionment existing within regions. We will be looking at Senator Coulter's proposition that the regions themselves may wish to regulate their boundaries. We want to see whether that will make the malapportionment worse. I do not see why it will not, going by past experience. We will want to look at the extent of malapportionment between zones. If that is to be as gross as we think it may be, we will comment appropriately as we come to learn more about the operation of this legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I indicate that the Government is pleased with the withdrawal of substituted amendment No. 70a in relation to the zones. I do not need to rehearse all the arguments that were put when we discussed a somewhat equivalent amendment suggested in relation to regional councils. It is interesting to note that this is not quite the same proposal because here the criterion set forth for the consideration of the Governor-General is that he shall:

SPEECH.PARA: as far as practicable, try to ensure that the total number of persons who will be entitled to vote in each zone at the next Regional Council elections will be equal;

There is nothing contained in the regional council provision about commonality of interest in looking at the cultural homogeneity of the population concerned. Obviously, there could have been an impact on the Aboriginal Co-ordinating Council. I know that Senator Boswell would be extremely conscious of that and no doubt he has brought his considerable experience and power to bear on Senator Peter Baume in relation to this matter. In so far as Tasmania might be affected-it certainly would be by this provision as would the Torres Strait Islanders--

TALK.START.PARA: —Tasmania is, Senator?
—Yes, it is. Naturally I share Senator Boswell's pleasure in the withdrawal by the Opposition of this proposed amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will not take up much of the Committee's time but I remind the Committee that the zones will elect a councillor, and that councillor will have one equal vote on the Commission, but those votes will have consequences which relate to the allocation of resources. I am concerned at the devaluation of urban votes which will occur. I express my view as a matter of democratic principle: I cannot understand why two Aboriginal or Islander people should have votes of different weight just because of the places in which they choose to reside. Having said that, I do not intend to persist with the matter any further.

SPEECH.PARA: At this stage I raise one more matter, which also relates to the electoral processes. I draw the attention of the Committee now to clause 99. That clause concerns persons entitled to vote at regional council elections. I wish here to raise again the questions of the electoral roll and who is entitled to vote, questions to which Senator Coulter has already made some reference today and to which I have made some reference. The clause raises a whole range of issues: first, what is Aboriginality and how we define it; secondly, the electoral rules; thirdly, the electoral roll; fourthly, the question of compulsory as against voluntary voting; and, fifthly, the question of residence as a qualification for voting. I will address these matters in order.

Let us look at the question of Aboriginality. Clause 99 (a) entitles an Aboriginal person or a Torres Strait Islander over 18 years of age to vote. Clause 4 defines an Aboriginal person as `a person of the Aboriginal race of Australia' and a Torres Strait Islander as a `descendant of an indigenous inhabitant of the Torres Strait Islands'. These definitions are little more than tautologies. Senator Coulter has drawn attention to this problem, not once but a number of times. He is absolutely correct. The accepted working definition of Aboriginality which is well known to us all is not used in this Bill at all. That working definition, a very useful and practical one, is that persons should be of Aboriginal descent, should identify themselves as Aboriginal and should be accepted as such in the community in which they live. That is the working definition of Aboriginality. We have here a different definition. As I say, it is a tautologous definition. It will give rise to trouble.

I think Senator Coulter drew attention to this matter in the dissenting report that he wrote for the Senate Select Committee on the Administration of Aboriginal Affairs. I do not believe the Government has addressed or has responded to the point that has been made. The Government has not addressed or responded to very many of the points which were made. But this is one which will cause the Government some difficulty and trouble. The definition is essentially a very subjective one. It will be very difficult to interpret in a court of law and it may be open to abuse, especially if a dominant faction wants to keep out a minority. I understand that there is some case law which relates to Senator Tate's State of Tasmania. The case involving the Tasmanian Aboriginal Centre Inc. and the Tasmanians of Aboriginal Descent Association actually addressed the question of what an Aboriginal person is and how one defines it.
The Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills has addressed this matter. In its report the Committee says in relation to clause 99 (a), concerning the entitlement to vote:
This paragraph lists one of the entitlements to vote in Regional Council elections-`that the person is an Aboriginal person or a Torres Strait Islander'.

There is no provision for determining when the entitlement is satisfied, and the Minister on page 6 of the Second Reading Speech suggests that a process for determining entitlement to vote has been arrived at and will presumably be included in the Electoral Rules to be made pursuant to clause 109.
The Committee sought a clarification of the mechanism by which a person denied eligibility to vote is able to have that decision reviewed.
The Minister has responded . . .
that is, to the Scrutiny of Bills Committee. I continue:
The Committee has sought clarification of the mechanisms proposed by which a person denied eligibility to vote is able to have the decision reviewed.

The electoral rules to be made pursuant to clause 110 will provide for voters to certify that they are Aboriginal or Torres Strait Islander persons. They will also provide for liaison officers who will be engaged to assist in the conduct of the election. Where a person is unable to satisfy the liaison officer that they are in fact Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander persons their vote will be set aside.
Voters challenged by the liaison officer will have eight days from the date of the election to satisfy the senior liaison officer for the region of their eligibility.
Finally, voters who have been unable to satisfy the senior liaison officer will be able to appeal to the Court of Disputed Elections.

The Minister referred the Scrutiny of Bills Committee to clause 137 and schedule 4. That is a very onerous set of provisions to put on an Aboriginal person. Senator Coulter's proposition-one with which I agree-is that eligibility to vote should be determined well ahead of any election. It should not be a matter to be determined on election day when one appears before a liaison officer. Then it is dependent entirely on the goodwill of the liaison officer whether or not a person satisfies him that he is qualified to vote. If a person is challenged the onus for proving that he is qualified to vote rests with him, and he has eight days in which to do it. There will be many problems in relation to this definition of Aboriginality. I was looking to Senator Coulter ahead of this debate to try to do something to resolve this problem.

Let us look then at the question of the electoral rules. We have the Minister's assurance that this matter will be clarified by the rules made under clause 110. Maybe it will; maybe it will not. I would like to see the rules. I think I would have to take that assurance with more than a grain of salt at this stage. This Bill has been before us in one form or another for more than a year and a half. Where are the electoral rules? Is it the intention of the Government to proceed quickly to an election once this legislation becomes law, is given royal assent and proclaimed? We want to see the electoral rules. We should be able to have them here because, until we see them, we cannot make judgments about what the Minister means when he says, `It will all become clear when we see the electoral rules to be made under clause 110'.

TALK.START.PARA: —What is that-`Just trust us; the cheque will be in the mail in the morning'?

—That is right; the Minister is saying, `Just trust us'. Why should this clause be adopted before we see and can examine and test the electoral rules? I am worried about the electoral processes which are provided here because, unlike any other member of the Committee present today, I have supervised a National Aboriginal Conference (NAC) election-at least, I have been accountable and responsible for it. I remind the Committee, as I think I have reminded it before, that I had to appoint an electoral ombudsman.
—A very distinguished person.

—Yes; it was former Senator Neville Bonner. He heard not one complaint but a myriad of complaints about election stealing from the various NAC electorates. Not only that; in the end he had to set one of the elections aside because it had been stolen. People had been bussed in and had enrolled on the spot, and their votes had been accepted. That election, which was held in the mid-west of New South Wales, had to be conducted again.
—It would never happen in the ALP.

—I think Senator Tate just said something about Enmore. So the question of the electoral rules remains quite unsatisfactory. We then come to the question of the electoral roll, which is quite important stuff. If the Government cannot get this right the whole process may fall into disrepute. The Senate Select Committee on the Administration of Aboriginal Affairs attempted, in paragraphs 2.122 to 2.133-that is, 12 paragraphs-to deal with related issues of compulsory or voluntary rolls and compulsory or voluntary voting. I will not read the paragraphs, but the report of the Senate Select Committee canvasses the arguments for and against compulsory voting. It says that they are finely balanced and indeed they are. It reminds us that a major cause of the failure of the NAC was the poor turnout of voters at elections. I have already referred this morning to the figure of 15 per cent, which is about what we had. If we want the newly elected bodies to be really representative we have to have a decent turnout. I cannot say whether the poor turnout was due to the electoral procedures or to the perception that the NAC was not politically significant, but there is some concern about whether voting should be compulsory or voluntary. The Select Committee reports that it has considered the question of an electoral roll of all voters. Going further, in paragraph 2.126 it says:

SPEECH.PARA: However some of the current requirements of the ATSIC Bill itself provide a case for electoral rolls. A number of provisions in the legislation are tied to decisions of a proportion of regional or zonal population.

Indeed they are. I have already referred to the fact that one clause refers to the trigger mechanism whereby 25 per cent of the eligible voters may petition the Minister to consider removing a regional council-that is, 25 per cent of the so-called electorate number. This is not the number of people registered to vote or the number of people who voted; it is the number of potential voters, which is really not good enough. The Bill also provides for the recall of a commissioner-this is no longer just an optional trigger-where the Minister receives a valid petition signed by 75 per cent of the sum of the regional electorate numbers in the zone-again potential electors.

The definition of an electorate number, a definition used in the Bill, may vary during the term of a regional council or a commissioner. It is determined by a ministerial notice issued under clauses 75 or 89 and it will refer to the number of persons who are entitled to vote at the next election. The number may fortuitously change, very conveniently, to assist in recall procedures. But if the electorate number is determined under clause 96 it would refer to the number of formal votes cast in the previous election. If the electorate number relates to the number of formal votes cast at the previous election this could produce an entirely different result.

The clause to which I refer was quoted by the Senate Committee, which recommended that the population in each instance should be the population on an electoral roll. This was the recommendation of a Senate select committee with representatives from four parties, chaired by Senator McMullan and including Senator Coulter, Senator Boswell and me.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating the need for an electoral roll. As my colleague Senator Peter Baume said, it was the unanimous recommendation of the Senate Select Committee on the Administration of Aboriginal Affairs that such a roll be established. From memory, it was Senator Coulter who led the charge on this issue. I see him nodding his head in agreement. He was adamant that such a roll would have to be established if this Bill were to receive the support of the Australian Democrats. I am not sure what Senator Coulter's position is at the moment but I have always thought that he was a man of his word and would not renege on commitments that he made to the Committee and Aboriginal people. I hope that I will not be disappointed, but unfortunately in this place we are disappointed sometimes because people renege on what they have stated previously in strong terms. I hope that Senator Coulter will not disappoint me today.

SPEECH.PARA: The Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission Bill, if we are to make it work, will need an iron lung at the best of times. I do not want again to go through the debate as to why ATSIC will not work and how it is culturally inappropriate, but if it is to have any relativity to the needs of the Aboriginal people some roll will have to be established that will give a commitment to democratically elected regional councils and, ultimately, zonal councils.

If we go through the farce that we had under the National Aboriginal Conference we will have such things happening as when the candidate took the ballot box around in the back seat of his car to solicit votes. As he was also the representative, he took them back to the office and counted them. That is what happened under the previous legislation. All sorts of rorts went on. If Senator Coulter does not want to see those rorts repeated and if he wants this legislation to have any slim chance of working to give Aboriginals and Torres Strait Islanders a reasonable chance of being represented and of having some electoral process, then he must support his idea. In other words, if this Committee does not vote for a roll then we may as well tear this legislation up as it will just not work. It does not have an ice-cream's chance in hell of working unless there is a roll for people who are interested in joining in the processes that ATSIC is supposed to deliver to them. Unless that happens, I think we have wasted five weeks of the Senate's time and eight or nine months of the time of the Senate Select Committee.
