SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Both Senator Peter Baume and Senator Boswell are absolutely correct in pointing out that these are the sections of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Bill which have caused me the greatest amount of concern. They are also correct in saying that unless in some way or other these procedures are clarified, ATSIC runs the risk of not succeeding. As I have already indicated this morning, getting some modification of these sections has been a source of considerable debate between me and the Minister. I have also indicated that I wanted to speak on these matters. This might be an appropriate time to lay down some of those arguments.

SPEECH.PARA: I reject Senator Boswell's claim that we are going to see ballot boxes carried around in the back seats of cars. The Bill clearly lays down that elections will be conducted under the control of the Australian Electoral Commission. I would think that that is an adequate protection against that sort of abuse of the electoral process. However, Senator Baume raised the issue of the number of people participating in the National Aboriginal Conference (NAC) elections. He did not go quite so far as I would have gone. When the number of people participating in an electoral process fell sufficiently, I believe the majority of Aboriginal people saw the NAC as being somewhat irrelevant and not representative. It was in a sense a self-reinforcing process. To the extent that the NAC was not seen as relevant, fewer people involved themselves in voting and the NAC did become less relevant. It is for that reason that it is extremely important that the largest number of Aboriginal people possible be involved in the election of the initial regional councils. If a large number are involved then they will see ATSIC as relevant and as representing their interests, and the numbers will grow. If, on the other hand, a small number are involved in the election then the majority of Aboriginal people will see ATSIC as not representing their interests, the numbers are likely to fall and ATSIC is likely to go the way of the NAC. The matter of the electoral process is an important crunch point.

Involved in this matter are the questions of the definition of an Aboriginal person, the electoral process, rolls, and compulsion. I will pick up firstly the definition of an Aboriginal person. On a number of occasions I have gone on the record as saying that the definition in this Bill is tautological; it does not really explain anything at all. When this was pointed out the Minister correctly said that this definition, or words very close to it, had been written into a number of Bills and the interpretation of those words has been given by the courts. The very fact that it has been necessary to go to the courts to find out what those words mean is an indication to me that almost certainly the words in this Bill will be tested and there will be some Aboriginal people disadvantaged by that process.

Senator Baume also pointed out that in interpreting these words, or words very similar to this, the courts, on a number of occasions, have come up with what has been described as the working definition. That working definition really falls into two parts when we look at it: either a person is Aboriginal by reason of establishing descent from a person of the Aboriginal race of Australia-that is a criterion which cannot be satisfied by a number of genuine Aboriginal people because in many instances they were removed from their Aboriginal parents as children and brought up by surrogate white parents-or alternatively the person identifies him or herself as a person of the Aboriginal race of Australia and is identified as such by the community. It is a two-part definition-either people can satisfy the first part, descent from an Aboriginal person, or, secondly, they can identify themselves as persons of the Aboriginal race and be identified as such by the community.

In meetings with the Minister I sought to have that definition written into the legislation, initially as an alternative but secondly as an additional explanatory definition. The argument that was raised against that definition was that to do so might cause the Bill to fall foul of the Constitution. You will recall, Mr Deputy Chairman, that in 1967 a constitutional change was made which gave the Federal Government certain powers with respect to Aboriginal people. A definition which could be in any way construed as excluding a person who was an Aboriginal would, if that were established, cause the whole Bill to fail on constitutional grounds. I looked very closely at that and it seemed to me that that possibility was extremely remote because two things would have to happen for a case along those lines to succeed. We should remember that on a number of occasions the courts have interpreted the words which are in this Bill and have consistently come up with a working definition. The first plank of disallowance of this legislation on constitutional grounds would be to establish an alternative definition, different from that which the courts have consistently used, and that that definition would have to be ruled to be unconstitutional. Secondly, we would have to establish that there was a person who satisfied this totally new definition. I think that is extremely unlikely. For that reason it seems to me very unlikely that this Bill could fail on constitutional grounds by reason of clarification of the definition of an Aboriginal person.

I put on the record, to clarify this matter, that I propose that the Minister write the working definition into the regulations when the regulations under this Bill are compiled so that it becomes absolutely clear that the definition as judged to be constitutional remains in the Bill. However, if-and, I believe, when-a genuine Aboriginal person turns up to vote and his Aboriginality is challenged, that working definition will be in the regulations and will allow a person to easily establish that he is an Aboriginal person.

That brings me to the second question, which is the matter of the construction of a roll and the point at which a roll is constructed. When I have spoken, principally with the media, on this question of roll, the immediate response has been, `But is it not racist to establish a roll?'. I put on the record the obvious fact that a roll is constructed by the very act of Aboriginal people voting. There will be a list of names of those people who have voted. That will be the roll. It will be constructed after the event. That list of names will contain only names of people who are of the Aboriginal race of Australia. So a roll will be constructed by the process of this legislation. The question arises: when is the roll to be constructed?

Senator Peter Baume is quite right in saying that I would prefer that the roll was constructed well before the election and that when the election is held the processes of determining who is eligible have been got out of the way so that a person merely turns up and votes, as people do in any normal State or Federal election. That would make the whole process of challenge and everything else much easier.

The method of counting at this election will be by proportional representation-essentially a Senate-type counting process, in which one cannot begin to count for the result of the election until the total number of valid votes is known. Then those votes must be divided by the number of places to be filled plus one to obtain a quota. Then the rest of the count can proceed. Only one vote needs to be outstanding and to be under challenge to prevent that process from proceeding. The way to get around that is to then exclude those votes which have perhaps been properly cast but over which there is a challenge after some interval of time, so that one can then get on with the process of election. That necessarily means that there are people who are genuinely Aboriginal, genuinely on the electoral roll and genuinely members of that region but whose vote will be excluded because the process of challenge is mixed with the process of the election. Certainly, for those reasons, I would prefer the situation in which a roll was constructed before the event, and then that roll became the basis of the election.

The last point I make in relation to these clauses and these matters in general is that Senator Peter Baume is quite correct in relation to clause 110 and the rules for the election not being written down. On a number of occasions I have sought from the Minister and the Minister's office a copy of those rules. I have been told consistently that the rules have not even been written down. I regard this as quite unsatisfactory. It is a key element in the process. I come back to the point that if a small number of Aboriginal people are involved in the election in the first instance and the majority of Aboriginal people form the impression that ATSIC is not relevant to their needs, then ATSIC runs the risk of failing, because, progressively, fewer and fewer people will see it as relevant and fewer and fewer people will involve themselves in the election process, as happened with the NAC.

One of the ways of overcoming that will be to go down this alternative road. As I have indicated on several other clauses where I think the logic of the argument has lain with Senator Peter Baume, the Australian Democrats believe, on balance, that to proceed with this legislation is the right course to give to Aboriginal people the opportunity of self-management and self-determination.

In conclusion, I make an earnest plea to the Minister to do a number of things: to accept that the working definition should be written into the regulations under ATSIC so that there is absolute clarity in relation to who is eligible and who is not eligible; to give very serious consideration to establishing within the rules for election that there be rolls constructed before the election and that the matters of challenge on Aboriginality be sorted out at that stage; and to give serious consideration to making voting on the basis of those rolls compulsory. I believe that is as far as I can go. I believe that is the correct way to go, and I make the plea that the Minister carry those matters through.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Several matters have been raised in the course of this committee discussion, which has not actually focused on any particular amendment but which, nevertheless, is quite properly taking advantage of the committee stage to look at several matters. As far as the definition of an Aboriginal person is concerned, honourable senators will be aware that it is extremely important that the legislation be constitutionally valid. For that reason, whilst it looks tautologous, one can understand-and I think Senator Coulter himself expressed some misgivings about the way in which these definitions might become subject to legal challenge-that it has been thought best to confine as simply as possible the definitions so that it is beyond challenge as a constitutionally valid category. For that reason, Senator Coulter's proposal for a definition of Aboriginality was not acceptable to the Government.

SPEECH.PARA: However, I will take on board-I know that that is a hackneyed phrase-his point that he would like to see in the regulations under the Act a working definition of `Aboriginal person' which encompasses the sorts of matters that at one stage he thought might be included in the principal Act as a definition of `Aboriginality' or `Aboriginal person'. Quite obviously, that would require consideration by the Attorney-General's Department and advice would need to be sought to ensure that the regulations kept within the Act. Obviously, if Senator Coulter's definition was intra vires the Act and, therefore, intra vires the Constitution, that would be acceptable. If it was thought that it might go outside the Act, it would be ultra vires the statute to start with and, therefore, unconstitutional. That would be dangerous. Obviously, there would have to be a very certain assessment by legal advisers that what Senator Coulter proposes might be done in the regulations could be done in a way which was not ultra vires the Act and at the same time unconstitutional.

As to the question of the electoral rules themselves, senators are expressing some dismay and concern that they have not got those rules before them. They have not yet been drafted, as I am advised. With the priorities in the drafting areas of government, it is only when the legislation is clearly passed that that may get the absolute priority category that would then be deserved. But the Committee will be aware that when the rules are made they will be disallowable. Clause 110 (8) states:
Rules made by the Minister under subsection (1) are a disallowable instrument for the purposes of section 46a of the Acts Interpretation Act 1901.

Quite clearly, these rules will come back to the Senate, and no doubt they will be subject to very close scrutiny by Senator Coulter, Senator Peter Baume, Senator Boswell and others. It is at that stage that the way in which the rules are proposed by the Minister can meet with the approval or disapproval of this chamber and, therefore, be allowed to operate or, in fact, be disallowed. It is a very powerful position for this chamber to be in. I say `this chamber'; the House of Representatives shares the power in theory but we know that it is only in this chamber that it would actually be exercised. I think that is a major safeguard which can allay some of the worries and concerns of the Committee.

A separate roll-and I have never put this argument; I know that Senator Coulter would never include any racist intent in its com- position, although some could argue that to have such a roll even put together might suggest that this was a different category of Australian citizen-could be used in a malicious way by white supremacist groups or even international organisations which might point at us and say that we have an apartheid-type roll. I have never felt that that was the main argument against the composition of an Aboriginal roll. It seems to me that when we look at the question of Aboriginal people voluntarily placing themselves on such a roll, we realise that it could lead to a lot of pressure from potential regional councillors or persons concerned with the hierarchy and the possibility of gaining office under ATSIC. They could put inordinate pressure on some people to get on the roll; others they would not induce to get on the roll. In fact, they might induce them not to get on the roll.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is exactly why you need a roll.

—We need a compulsory roll such as is already in place under the Commonwealth Electoral Act. That brings me to the second point that I worry about. If we have an ATSIC-type education program, which quite clearly we would need as a preliminary to voting taking place, telling people that they could voluntarily bring themselves forward and get themselves on the electoral roll, quite conceivably we could create confusion which would lead to Aboriginal people wondering whether they really needed to get on the Commonwealth roll. I can see that there would be confusion in their minds about whether the compulsory requirement to be on the Commonwealth electoral roll would be something which they would tend to think had been displaced by this very intense campaign that would be waged to let them exercise a choice about going on the voluntary Aboriginal roll. That would be to the detriment of the Commonwealth roll. For that reason I think that would be a disadvantage overall to the work of democracy in Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: As I said, what impresses me is not the taunt that this might give ground for racist sentiment in Australia; it is more the question of the way in which the voluntary roll might be worked by candidates in a way which advantaged them and in a way which disadvantaged the Commonwealth electoral roll.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Justice (Senator Tate) has promised nothing in response to Senator Coulter's suggestion.
—Of course I have.

—The Minister has said he will `take on board' a suggestion. I ask the Committee what that means. In terms of some kind of outcome, it does not mean anything. All Senator Coulter has asked for in relation to the definition of `Aboriginality' is that the definition of `Aboriginality' be included in the regulations to be made under the Act. Taking it on board really means that it will be looked at. It does not mean it will happen. I will come back to that point in a moment. I remind honourable senators of the unanimous recommendation of the Senate Select Committee on the Administration of Aboriginal Affairs in relation to the question of a roll. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee recommends that this population should be, in each instance, the population of people on an electoral roll. While placing one's name on the electoral roll should be voluntary, voting should be compulsory thereafter for those whose names are on the roll. The recall provisions should be exercisable only by those on the electoral roll.

Those of us who were on the Committee will understand not only that it is internally consistent but that it leads to a resolution of many of the other problems we have identified in this discussion in the last little while. Any other resolution will not work. The next paragraph in the Committee's report states:
The advantages of constructing these rolls before polling day and of compulsory voting-
that is, the recommendation for compulsory voting-
are closely related.
The Committee's report then sets out seven or eight points. They are:
(a) voter rolls clarify the recall provisions;
(b) prior construction removes the possibility of challenge on polling day and speeds the counting of the poll;

Senator Coulter is quite right. There has to be only one matter before the Court of Disputed Returns and a regional council may not be able to be elected. That is a distinct possibility under the Labor Party proposal. The report continues:
(c) compulsory voting removes the possibility of coercion to vote or not to vote;
I turn the coercion argument right around. There is an advantage in having the kind of roll recommended by the Select Committee. The report states:
(d) compulsory voting makes voting similar in all respects to State and Federal elections. It therefore serves an education function for those not yet familiar with these elections;
(e) it will ensure that electoral officers will make every attempt to contact voters in remote regions.
(f) it ensures the greatest degree of representativeness of the outcome; and

(g) non-compulsory voting will generate friction. A small number of voters may return a Regional Council that is immediately challenged by those who did not vote. If all vote, all are represented in and responsible for the outcome. This will be a particularly difficult area in the intial stages under the proposed legislation as rolls will only be constructed after an election and will only contain the names of those who voted, and not those who were eligible to vote.

I will not quote further from the report as I do not wish to go on too long. Senator Coulter is absolutely right: There will be an electoral roll. The argument that it is racist to have an electoral roll is nonsense. It does not hold water. The argument was not made by Senator Tate but it has been made by other people. The roll will exist post-hoc. There will be an electoral roll and there will need to be such a roll to establish an electoral number. There needs to be an electoral number to enable the recall provisions to be triggered. So the arguments against the existence of an Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander electoral roll are nonsense. If the Labor Government is going to proceed down the road of establishing, as it were, a constituent assembly, the existence of an electoral roll follows. If it goes down the road of having recall provisions which are triggered by a percentage of the electoral number, the existence of an electoral roll is necessary.

In relation to the question of Aboriginality, I remind the Committee that a report by the Auditor-General was tabled in the Senate yesterday. It is the final report on a special audit of the Aboriginal Development Commission and the Department of Aboriginal Affairs. On page 29 there is the heading `Definition of Aboriginal'. The Auditor-General makes the point that `benefits available under the Aboriginal Development Commission Act are restricted to Aborigines and Torres Strait Islanders'. He then discusses the definition. First of all, in relation to the statutory definition, he says:
The Act defines Aboriginals to mean members of the Aboriginal race of Australia and descendants of indigenous inhabitants of the Torres Strait Islands.
At paragraph 3.49 he goes on to say:
In practice ADC uses a working definition adopted by successive governments since 1977:
`Aboriginal means a person of Aboriginal or Torres Strait Island descent who identifies as an Aboriginal or Torres Strait islander and is accepted as such by the community in which he or she lives.'
The Auditor goes on to make the point that legal advice was then sought from the Attorney-General's Department. At paragraph 3.52 the Auditor-General said:
In a detailed advising the Department said that the working definition was a valid means of determining whether a person belongs to the Aboriginal race within the meaning of the ADC Act.

Senator Coulter's request that that working definition appear somewhere is entirely proper. I want to say to Senator Coulter, so that there can be no doubt about it, that the Opposition shares his concerns about the question of the definition of Aboriginality. He is correct. We share his concern about the question of the need for an electoral roll in the terms in which that was recommended unanimously by Labor, Liberal, National and Democrat members of the Select Committee. We support his statements about compulsory voting. We say to him: this is a committee stage debate in which our duty to the Senate is to try to examine and improve the clauses of this legislation. If Senator Coulter believes in what he is saying, he should move amendments to give effect to it. We have moved many amendments and have many more to move. If he moves the amendments, we will support him.

If he did so I do not believe that the Minister would not proceed with the Bill. I cannot believe that amendments introduced by a Committee of the Whole in the Senate in a genuine attempt to overcome some difficulties and failings within the Bill would not be acceptable to the Government. Not only that: these would be recommendations which arise out of unanimous all-party recommendations of a Senate select committee on which Senator Coulter served. Senator Coulter should move the amendments, and we will support him. If he wants people to take him seriously, now is the moment for him to act and ask the Committee to adopt what he believes. We will support him. This is the moment when his various stated intentions can be put to the test. He will have our support. We have deferred to him on this matter because it is common knowledge that these were matters which he introduced and on which he was able to convince us by the force of argument. We stand ready to support his proposals that there be a role in terms provided by the Senate Select Committee, that there be compulsory voting in the terms which Senator Coulter himself has put to us. I would like to support Senator Coulter in his attempt to get an assurance from the Government that the working definition would be included in the regulations to come down under the Act. Having said those things, I indicate to Senator Coulter that he has only to move and he will have the support of the Opposition.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think that is the one I don't belong to!

—Senator Baume and Senator Coulter are both doctors and are probably on rolls. Senator Coulter would belong to some sort of social club, whether it is a bowls club or a football club. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —First of all, I pick up several points that the Minister for Justice (Senator Tate) made in relation to the electoral roll and racism. This argument was raised frequently when I raised the issue of a roll both during and immediately after the time of the Senate Select Committee on the Administration of Aboriginal Affairs. I simply repeat-the Minister did not seem to pick up the point, but Senator Peter Baume stressed it, and it needs to be stressed, apparently-that by the very creation of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission (ATSIC), and the fact that people of Aboriginal race exclusively will vote, the list of those people who have voted will be the roll and it will be established after the event. I am calling for it to be established before the event, to clarify the eligibility for voting, and separate that from the time of the election.

SPEECH.PARA: Another issue which the Minister raised in discussion in relation to racism is that if a roll is established before the event, in the more conventional way, it may become an instrument of harassment of Aboriginal people. He used the example of the outback of New South Wales. I pointed out to him, and it seems to me to be a perfectly valid protection against that eventuality, that the role would be kept by the Australian Electoral Commission and may be available only to people who can establish a bona fide reason for getting access to it. One might require people who wanted access to the roll to sign a statutory declaration setting out why they wanted it. In that case, the roll would not fall into the hands of those who might use it as a way of harassing people who have put their names on it and, therefore, are identified and defined as Aboriginal people. However, I think the possibility is extremely remote. I would have thought that, in most communities, those who are so minded to harass Aboriginal people would know who the Aboriginal people were anyway. It really should not be a problem.

The Minister also raised the question of pressure on people to put their names on the roll. Of course, if pressure is going to be exerted, the same pressure will be exerted to get people to vote or not to vote. One does not alter the operation of pressure by having or not having a roll. I would argue that, on the contrary, the establishment of the roll and the separation of the voting procedure from that would, if anything, reduce that pressure. Bearing in mind that those whose names are on the roll will have to vote compulsorily, and that once one's name was on the roll it would remain on the roll, there should be a progressive increase in the number of people on the roll, a progressive increase in the participation rate in the election process. The process would, therefore, become more democratic and would reduce the possibility of pressure being exerted at the time of election.

Finally, the Minister raised the issue of confusion between the election processes for State and Federal parliaments and the election processes for ATSIC if both the placing of the name on the roll and participation in the election were compulsory. I think the difference, and it has to be borne in mind, is that there are Aboriginal people in the community-that is, people who could establish their Aboriginality by reason of the working definitions which we have already mentioned-who would choose not to participate in the ATSIC process. They may be people who could easily establish Aboriginality by descent-they may be one-sixteenth Aboriginal, and the rest of their racial heritage European-who have totally integrated into the white community and do not wish to participate.

Clearly, one cannot link the definition of Aboriginality with the compulsory placing on the ATSIC roll of the names of all those people who would satisfy that definition. The placing of the name on the roll must be voluntary but, having chosen to put one's name on the roll, the rest of the process becomes consistent with other elections; in other words, compulsory voting. Clause 110 (6) states:

the Minister shall have regard to the desirability of providing for Regional Council elections to be conducted in a manner similar to the manner in which elections for the Parliament are conducted . . .

The distance one can go is determined by the matters I have just raised. There are Aboriginal people by definition who would not want to participate in the ATSIC process and, therefore, the placing of the name on the roll should not be compulsory. That is the difference.

I turn specifically to the pleas which Senator Peter Baume and Senator Boswell have made. The rules for the conduct of elections appear under clause 110. We have not yet seen those rules. For months I have been seeking a copy of the rules from the Minister so that we can see these XYZ rules. I nearly used an unparliamentary term. The Minister has consistently said that the rules have not yet even been drafted. We need to see the rules for the conduct of elections because they will contain the clauses dealing with the construction of rolls, whether the placing of names on rolls is voluntary or compulsory and whether participation in the election itself becomes compulsory. That will be the time at which we will be seeking to accept or reject those rules. That is why I am making a plea to the Minister now. Although this debate arose out of our consideration of clause 99 when Senator Peter Baume first raised it about an hour ago, we have got on to it now and this is an appropriate time to deal with it.

No clause of the Bill before us can be amended to achieve what we have been debating. It is the rules which would be made under clause 110 which need to be addressed. It is a great pity that we have not seen those rules. That is why I am making a plea to the Minister to take back to Minister Hand the strong representations of the Senate in this matter, supported by the Australian Democrats and the Opposition, that, in the making of those rules or regulations, consideration be given to the inclusion of the working definition of `Aboriginal' and to the construction and use of rolls in the election. When those rules come before this chamber we will look at them very closely in the light of the comments that have been made. As the Minister himself has pointed out, those rules will be a disallowable instrument.

I understand that the legal position on the matter of definition is that if there is a conflict between a regulation and what is said in the relevant Act, to the extent that what is said in the regulations is inconsistent with the Act, it is simply invalid. I do not see any great danger in putting the working definition into regulations. I do not understand how the Minister can argue that one can put something in the regulations which could be inconsistent. I repeat the plea that there be clarification in those regulations, that we see the rules for the conduct of elections and that very serious consideration be given to the matters we have raised in the debate this morning.

ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

—I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security. I draw his attention to an answer given by the Director of the Institute of Family Studies, Dr Edgar, to Estimates Committee F last night. I asked Dr Edgar whether any research was available to prove that child poverty had been eliminated. As this is in direct conflict with the Prime Minister's recent statement that he has eliminated child poverty six months ahead of schedule, can the Minister tell me what research the Prime Minister was relying on when he made the statement?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: CONSUMER AFFAIRS

TALK.START.PARA: —At the outset the point needs to be made that it is quite apparent that we have a process in the Senate where late at night at an Estimates committee a particular senator has a revelation of new information that she or he might think is something quite stunning and startling and will bring down the Government and the Western economy. In reality, in the light of day, when we assess that information, we discover that it is not the startling information which, in this instance, Senator Walters might have seen it to have been. The other practice we also seem to have is that we are presented with somewhat selective and inadequate recitation of information that has been dragged out the night before. Senator Walters would probably do the Senate much more justice were she a bit more comprehensive in her recitation of what Dr Edgar said last night.

ANSWER.PARA: I have not seen the full transcript of that Estimates Committee hearing but I have seen parts of it. It occurred to me that someone in Dr Edgar's position would have been a bit more comprehensive in his acknowledgment of what the Government has done in this particular area and that he also would have been a bit more analytical and accurate in his use of the Henderson poverty line as an indicator for poverty.

We all acknowledge in this place-Senator Chaney has been one of those who have acknowledged it-that the Henderson poverty line is an inappropriate benchmark for the assessment of poverty in Australia. It is not a radical thing to say. It has been acknowledged for quite some time. Poverty lines in themselves as measures of poverty are always both arbitrary and imprecise. The Henderson poverty line-the one that Dr Edgar referred to and the one most widely known in Australia-has never been endorsed by any government, neither this one nor the previous one. We have to acknowledge that the Henderson poverty line was something that was indicated--

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Grimes used some as though he were endorsing it.

—We have quotes from both yourself and Senator Grimes questioning the appropriateness of the poverty line as a benchmark. It has never been used even though it has been available for about 14 or 15 years.
—You should go through some of those old debates, Shirley.

—It suffers from a number of deficiencies. As Senator Chaney says, we can go through some of the old debates. It is a pity that in going through the old debates Dr Edgar did not acknowledge some of the problems. We have to acknowledge that the Henderson poverty line suffers from being based on household expenditure data derived from a survey in New York in the 1950s.
—In New York?

—Senator Chaney knows that. It suffers from significant delays in updating-two years at the moment. One could say that I am probably saying now of it what Senator Chaney would have said of it a few years ago. It suffers from being inevitably arbitrary.
—I have not realised how convincing I was.

—We have to be cautious. Sometimes Senator Chaney is a bit more convincing than he thinks, at other times much less convincing. Last night at Estimates Committee F, Dr Edgar also referred to one part of the Government's programs in this area-not a comprehensive assessment of what the Government has done or what those measures have done in terms of child poverty. To that extent we have to look not only at the family allowance but also at a whole range of tax measures and structural support. We have to look at education support and the fact that, over the last five or six years, there has been a massive increase in the number of children staying on at school. We have to look at support by way of child-care places. We have to look at support by way of Medicare and that sort of service being available to all Australian families, with much more benefit to poorer families. We have to look at public housing and the fact that so many people have been able to benefit from public housing programs. We have to look at rent assistance for low income families.

ANSWER.PARA: As I have said, leaving that aside, we have to look at one basic thing that has happened under this Government: over a million jobs have been created during our term of office. I could go on and refer to structural accommodation assistance programs and so on, but the reality is that all these avenues of support for family income have to be taken into account. We must not take into account only financial measures; we also have to take into account measures such as JET and Newstart, which are really giving people in the greatest areas of need, and particularly sole parents, a chance, through a coordinated government response, for a new start. I believe that those sorts of factors were not adequately taken into account.

Let me go back to the basic point: this Government made a commitment in terms of child poverty. This Government has fulfilled a commitment to achieve benchmarks in this area which we think are more appropriate. Not only this Government but also independent commentators in the field think this is the way to go in terms of alleviating child poverty. We have achieved those benchmarks. We have also indexed them to ensure that they are not transitory; that they will stay in place. So Senator Walters should not come in here arguing about the Government's performance in this area.

I could go on and mention our performance as opposed to the performance of the previous Government. One statistic has to be noted for the record. This Government is not a government that, in every year of its term of office, has ensured that 50,000 more children have moved into categories of poverty. This Government is not a government that, in its last year of office, ensured that over 50,000 children were placed in that position. This Government cares and has poured a lot of money and resources into this area. We have approached the area comprehensively and I am sure that Dr Edgar's professional reputation would benefit if he took this into account.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I wish to ask a supplementary question. It is of no use the Minister coming in here and telling us that Dr Edgar does not know what he is talking about. As I have said, he is the Director of the Institute of Family Studies which does research on all aspects of family policy, not just on family allowance. The Minister made no attempt at all to answer my question. I repeat my question: Can the Minister tell me what research the Prime Minister relied upon to make his statement?

ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: CONSUMER AFFAIRS

TALK.START.PARA: —No matter how the Opposition tackles this area--

—You have had a supplementary question. We indulged your--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senator Walters has asked her question. I ask the Minister to reply through me.

—Has the attention of the Minister representing the Minister for Community Services and Health been drawn to a campaign by the Schizophrenia Fellowship of South Queensland Inc. for the urgent evaluation and approval of the neuroleptic medication known as clozapine? Is the Minister aware that this campaign is based on the claim that clozapine has been hailed by many respected medical practitioners as a breakthrough drug in the treatment of chronic schizophrenia? As the drug clozapine has now been approved by the United States Food and Drug Administration, can the Minister confirm whether this decision will expedite the evaluation process in Australia? If so, can the Minister give a time frame for approval or otherwise of clozapine?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —About five minutes before I came into the chamber my attention was drawn to the campaign seeking urgent evaluation and approval for the drug clozapine for the treatment of patients with schizophrenia, based on the claim that it was a breakthrough drug. Since the campaign may give an impression that clozapine is a brand new discovery, it is relevant to note that the first clinical trials were initiated overseas in the 1960s. The drug created interest at the time because it appeared to have fewer of the unpleasant side effects commonly associated with other drugs used to treat schizophrenia.

ANSWER.PARA: Unfortunately, in the six months following marketing of the drug in Finland in 1975, 13 patients developed a serious toxicity affecting the bone marrow and eight of them died. The problem was occurring also in other countries and, by April 1976, 45 cases had been reported, with 23 deaths. As a result, clinical use was either ceased or restricted and the manufacturer withdrew outstanding marketing applications worldwide. However, marketing of the drug continued in a number of countries where it was already available. There was no application to market the drug in Australia at the time, but two clinical trials using doses that were low and less than effective were completed here by 1975 without any serious complications.

Despite this worrying history I understand that Sandoz Australia Pty Ltd now intends to lodge an application to market the drug in Australia. It is to do this in the belief that accumulated clinical experience has shown clozapine to be effective in some patients who are poorly responsive to other drugs, and that death due to bone marrow damage can be avoided by rigorous surveillance of the white cells in the blood so that the drug can be stopped within several days of the damage occurring. I am aware that the application is supported by respected Australian medical practitioners.

In view of the potentially fatal toxicity of the drug, the evaluation process will need to be most thorough. I hope that members of the Schizophrenia Fellowship of South Queensland will perceive that their interests will be served best if the evaluation process is allowed to run its normal course and is not forced or otherwise interfered with as a consequence of its campaign or by the recent approval of clozapine in the United States. RELEASE
Minister for Employment, Education and Training
The Hon. J. S. Dawkins, M.P. 171/89
THOUSANDS OF STUDENTS TO HAVE
BETTER CHANCE OF LEARNING ABOUT
NATIONAL PARLIAMENT

Thousands of high school students from many parts of Australia will be encouraged to learn about the National Parliament and the political process following the introduction of the special Citizenship Visit Program to assist groups of students in outlying areas with the cost of travelling to the National Capital.

John Dawkins, the Minister for Employment, Education and Training, has introduced a program which will provide between $50 and $200 per student for high school pupils who have to travel more than 1,000 km from their schools to visit the national Parliament.

The Citizenship Visit Program will form part of an extensive education program coordinated by the Parliament which will take in the Electoral Education Centre, the National Library, the National Science and Technology Centre and the High Court of Australia.
Mr Dawkins announced the Citizenship Visit Program (CVP) with the Speaker of the House of Representatives, Mr Leo McLeay.

He said the CVP will encourage students to visit the national capital and provide some assistance for students who may have otherwise found the costs of travel a disincentive to take part in a school excursion to the Parliament.

``As the Senate Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training emphasised in its report on `Education for Active Citizenship', it is important,'' said Mr Dawkins, ``that all young Australians have a solid understanding of how our government and democracy works. First hand experience is one of the best ways to achieve this understanding.

``This new program will mean that distance and the cost of travelling that distance will not be such an obstacle for many students to visit Canberra and see the nation's Parliament and participate in the many activities on offer.

The Citizenship Visit Program will be piloted as a Project of National Significance and will be available to high school groups on school excursions travelling 1,000 kilometres or more to visit Parliament House.

Regardless of the type of transport, groups which have to travel between 1,000-1,999 road kilometres will receive a $50 subsidy per student, $100 for 2,000-3,000 km and $200 if the distance travelled is more than $3,000 km.
Students from Tasmania, however, will be eligible for the $100 subsidy irrespective of distance because of the need for them to pay more for the sea or air crossing of Bass Strait.
The Citizenship Visit Program will be administered by the office of the Sergeant-At-Arms who will account for the number of students on the school excursion and then make the payments.
Distances from Canberra will be calculated by road using the most favourable but not necessarily the shortest travel routes.
October 5, 1989
Enquiries
Wayne Burns
Mr Dawkins' media secretary

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Patterson yesterday asked me a question about a joint letter from the Telecom Australia Customer Services Manager for the Canberra-Queanbeyan district and the Minister for Telecommunications and Aviation Support, Ros Kelly. I said that I would provide an answer as soon as possible. I can confirm that the Minister for Telecommunications and Aviation Support has participated in a Telecom public awareness campaign designed to inform telephone subscribers in the Canberra-Queanbeyan district, the 062 area code, that their telephone numbers are shortly to have an extra digit, namely, a `2'. I should point out that the 062 area encompasses much more than the electorate of Canberra.

ANSWER.PARA: Mrs Kelly launched the Telecom public awareness campaign in Parliament House on 21 August in the presence of a number of members and senators. She did this at the request of the local manager of Telecom as Telecom is anxious to achieve as high a profile as possible for its public awareness campaign in order to ensure that its customers in the 062 district are fully informed of the change to their phone numbers. It is important that the message is received clearly by all subscribers and in good time so as to avoid problems with the printing of business stationery, et cetera. Telecom wants to minimise any disruption to business and households caused by the need to change phone numbers, and this can be achieved by an effective public awareness campaign.

The jointly signed letter to all residents in the 062 area, as opposed to including a message in telephone bills, was used because it is not possible easily to isolate 062 bills from all others. Telephone bills are produced centrally by Telecom.

I am informed that Telecom expects the public awareness campaign to be most effective due to the high public profile-and not just in the Canberra region-of Mrs Kelly. The Minister has made herself available to all government business enterprises in her portfolio to launch new service offerings, to open new premises and to generally publicise the good work they are doing. This is a most appropriate activity for a Minister. Mrs Kelly is to be commended for her energy and commitment. In this particular case, Mrs Kelly's involvement will greatly assist in a smooth transition to the new telephone numbers.

DEBATE.TITLE: ABORIGINAL DEVELOPMENT COMMISSION AMENDMENT BILL 1989AUSTRALIAN INSTITUTE OF ABORIGINAL AND TORRES STRAIT ISLANDER STUDIES BILL 1989ABORIGINAL AND TORRES STRAIT ISLANDER COMMISSION BILL 1989

PROCTEXT.PARA: ABORIGINAL AND TORRES STRAIT ISLANDER COMMISSION BILL 1989

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (73) Page 12, clause 17, lines 3 to 35, leave out the clause.
(74) Page 13, subclause 18 (2), line 6, leave out ``15, 16 or 17'', insert ``15 or 16''.
(75) Page 61, after clause 149 insert the following new clause:
Enterprise loans and grants
``149a. (1) The Corporation may, for the purpose of enabling or assisting Aboriginal persons and Torres Strait Islanders to engage in business enterprises:
(a) make loans, on such terms and conditions as are determined by the Corporation Board, to:
(i) Aboriginal persons and Torres Strait Islanders; or
(ii) Aboriginal or Torres Strait Islander corporations;
(b) subscribe for, or otherwise acquire, shares or stock in the capital of a company;
(c) make grants of money, on such terms and conditions as are determined by the Corporation Board, to Aboriginal or Torres Strait Islander corporations; and

(d) make payments in respect of the investigation or supervision of, or the provision of accounting services, management advice or technical assistance for or in relation to, a business enterprise in connection with which:
(i) moneys have been or may be applied in accordance with paragraph (a), (b) or (c);
(ii) property has been, or may be, acquired or otherwise dealt with pursuant to section 14 or acquired pursuant to a grant under section 15; or
(iii) a guarantee has been or may be given under section 19 or 150.

``(2) The loans that the Corporation may make under subsection (1) include, but are not limited to, loans for the purpose of the acquisition from the Corporation of shares or stock in the capital of a company.

``(3) The Corporation shall not exercise its powers under subsection (1) in relation to a business enterprise unless it is satisfied that the enterprise is likely to become, or continue to be, commercially successful.

``(4) In considering whether to exercise the powers of the Corporation under subsection (1), the Corporation Board shall have regard to the effect of the proposed exercise of power on the employment and training of Aboriginal persons and Torres Strait Islanders.''.

This group of amendments is the first group that deals with the Development Corporation, which I believe we now call the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commercial Development Corporation (ATSICDC). The Committee will know that during the various incarnations of this legislation the Development Corporation has had two different names, but we are now calling it the ATSICDC.

These three amendments are related. They relate to what should be the proper function of the Development Corporation. It is necessary to look at the Aboriginal Development Commission (ADC) because this Development Corporation will replace the Aboriginal Development Commission as a vehicle for Aboriginal economic development. The original concept of the Aboriginal Development Commission was that it would work to develop and enhance Aboriginal self-management within certain economic areas and it would do so by sticking to certain economic functions. The Department of Aboriginal Affairs, on the other hand, was to deal with certain social functions. So on the one hand there was enterprise and business development and on the other hand we had welfare functions which included matters such as housing and the provision of essential services.

During the genesis of ATSIC there were consultations within the portfolio and included in those was the ADC's own consideration of the Government's proposal. In March 1988 the ADC actually published what it called an alternative strategy for Aboriginal self-management in which it put down the views of the Aboriginal commissioners about the way in which ATSIC should be developed. The commissioners quite clearly saw the need for a distinction between economic development and social development and they proposed a structure in which those two functions were quite clearly separated.

I remind Senator Coulter that when he and I were on the Select Committee on the Administration of Aboriginal Affairs he particularly was aware of the need for this distinction between economic and social functions. It was this alternative strategy which was produced by the then commissioners of the ADC that partly annoyed the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Hand) and set the stage for their subsequent dismissal, their subsequent sacking. That strategy observed of ATSIC and of the Aboriginal Economic Development Corporation (AEDC), as it was then called, in the following terms:

Social welfare and economic development projects will be integrated and lumped together in the same organisation, thus creating a situation where the dissimilar objectives of each are likely to become confused at all levels.
That was the view of the former commissioners of the Aboriginal Development Commission. How right those sacked commissioners were! They also stated:

Economic development programs will only be partially separated between the AEDC and ATSIC. This will fragment resources. Also it will not allow the responsible integration of the program to the long term goals of financial self-sufficiency and self-management.
The commissioners then went on to say:
We believe that the different objectives are best pursued by different agencies.

Further, the independent consultants KPMG-Peat Marwick Hungerfords in their analysis of the management issues expected to arise under ATSIC also warned about what they called a confusion of objectives. They said:

The likely outcome is that social welfare objectives will come to dominate the activities of ATSIC to the detriment of economic self-sufficiency objectives and the overall achievement of program goals.

Those words fit in entirely with the thoughts of some of us who served on the Select Committee. The Government has had plenty of warning, but it has pushed ahead with ATSIC in the form in which it is now presented to us. The 1988 Bill had the AEDC tucked away in one corner, as it were, with limited functions and not really very much money. It was to be dominated by the elected commissioners of ATSIC. That provision alone carries a virtual guarantee that political and not commercial considerations would predominate. That was one of our worries about the Bill as it was then presented.

These matters were carefully considered by the Senate Select Committee on the Administration of Aboriginal Affairs. I refer honourable senators to recommendation 2 and to paragraphs 2.33 to 2.36. The Opposition has therefore had to determine what it wants to do. We have not proposed the transfer of the land function to the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Development Corporation. We could have done so; it would have been logical. However, we have picked up the intention of the Senate Select Committee proposal. We were impressed by the Senate Select Committee argument. Senator Coulter was a party to that report, as were Senator Boswell, Senator McMullan, Senator Devlin and I. I will quote from Senator Coulter's press statement of 12 April 1988.

TALK.START.PARA: —Was that 12 April?
—It was 12 April 1988, so it was a year and a half ago. The honourable senator then saw clearly what the problem was. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: An important recommendation which we are keen to see adopted by the Government but which it has rejected is that a greater proportion of the Aboriginal Development Commission (ADC) activities should be the responsibility of the Aboriginal Economic Development Corporation (AEDC).
That is the body we are now discussing under a different name. Senator Coulter's press statement continued:

. . . a greater proportion of the Aboriginal Development Commission activities should be the responsibility of the Aboriginal Economic Development Corporation than is envisaged in the Bill. We believe it is important to separate as much as possible the economic development and social welfare functions of Aboriginal Affairs.

Senator Coulter was right in what he said in April 1988. It is desirable that those functions be separated. This is not our legislation. We do not think it is good legislation, but the Committee's duty is to try to improve it. Accordingly, we have moved the three amendments. I will take honourable senators quickly through them. The first occurs at page 12 where we wish to leave out clause 17. These fit in together. The second amendment is to clause 18. It is a consequential amendment, merely changing certain numbering consequential upon clause 17 being removed.

The third of the amendments is at page 61. It proposes to insert a new clause 149a after clause 149. We seek to outline certain things the Corporation may do. I will take the Committee through those quickly. Under our proposal the Corporation may, for the purpose of enabling or assisting Aboriginal persons and Torres Strait Islanders to engage in business enterprises, make loans. We go through to whom those loans might be made. The Corporation may also subscribe for, or otherwise acquire, shares or stock and make grants of money on such terms and conditions as are determined by the Board. Our proposal also allows for the Corporation to make payments in respect of the investigation or supervision of, or the provision of accounting services, management services and the like for such enterprises. It goes on to say:

. . . The loans the Corporation may make under subsection (1) include, but are not limited to, loans for the purpose of the acquisition from the Corporation of shares or stock in the capital of a company.

. . . The Corporation shall not exercise its powers under subsection (1) in relation to a business enterprise unless it is satisfied that the enterprise is likely to become, or continue to be, commercially successful.

That is to say that we wish the ATSIC Development Corporation to concentrate its mind on increasing the economic independence of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people and the continued economic viability of business enterprises with which they are connected. There is one other small subclause. We are concerned here with the proper division between the welfare functions which are properly those of ATSIC and the economic development functions. We are not merely following our own wishes and desires. We are responding to a press release made by Senator Coulter and to recommendations made by the Senate Select Committee. This is a proper, necessary and reasonable group of amendments. It will help to separate in the Bill what needs to be separated. It will not prevent these activities being carried out; it will merely outline the activities which belong to ATSIC; and those that belong to the Development Corporation. We believe they will enhance the operation of both bodies. The amendments are reasonably drawn and we commend them to the Committee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Basically, Senator Peter Baume might be confusing economic development with commercial development. The Opposition has virtually transferred, holus bolus, clause 17 and tried to make it something which the Commercial Development Corporation could undertake. While dealing with economic development, it is prepared to do so on concessional terms. It has in mind the fact that in order to enable Aboriginal persons and Torres Strait Islanders to engage in business enterprises, we may have to make loans which are of a concessional kind. That is quite different from the type of charter given in clause 145 to the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commercial Development Corporation. Clause 145 (1) reads:

SPEECH.PARA: In performing its functions the Corporation shall act in accordance with sound business principles.

That is really the distinction: the Corporation is to act in accordance with commercial principles; ATSIC is permitted by clause 17 to act in accordance with non-commercial principles, it could be said, though the overall aim will be to enable Aboriginals and Torres Strait Islanders to make some entry into the business, commercial and trading life of their communities and, indeed, the nation. The sound business principles to which the Corporation is to have regard are an important distinction from those matters which ATSIC might have regard to under clause 17. That is why the clear distinction is constantly reinforced. The Corporation will have a much harder commercial edge to its operations than was the case with the Aboriginal Development Commission and the concessional or even welfare oriented economic assistance given to Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander communities will not be its concern.

The need for the Corporation is generally recognised. Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander businesses need a commercial partner with which to operate. It will establish links with all the existing financial institutions of the country and provide that sort of guarantee and security to those institutions as they involve themselves with Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander projects. Access to commercial sources of finance for those projects is extremely important. The clear mandate of the Corporation, undiluted in the way in which the Opposition seeks it to be, will be important in securing that important profile as a hard commercial operation of the Corporation.

The Corporation, as honourable senators will know, will be required to prepare a corporate plan. That will make it even clearer that the Corporation has to operate in a commercial manner. That is quite different from the intention of clause 17 and the way in which it is structured. On that ground, the clear distinction that is sought to be achieved in this legislation ought to be achieved so that there is no confusion such as we discovered from time to time. Senator Tambling would remember from evidence given during Senate Estimates committee hearings that when the ADC made grants of money for economic development, one was quite often left with the feeling they were more welfare oriented than commercially oriented. I think that confusion would be repeated if clause 17 were to be transferred from the ATSIC jurisdiction and included within the Corporation's jurisdiction.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —This whole area has caused a great deal of heartsearching on the part of the Australian Democrats. I recall the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Expenditure inquiry into the mixing of welfare and economic development functions. If I recall correctly, that Committee reported in about 1983-84. That inquiry, which was into the Aboriginal Development Commission (ADC), recommended a clear necessity to separate the economic development functions from the social welfare functions. Under the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission (ATSIC) these functions are to some extent being re-mixed. As Senator Peter Baume pointed out, this caused the Senate Select Committee on the Administration of Aboriginal Affairs some concern and continues to cause me some concern.

SPEECH.PARA: I have debated this matter at some length with the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Hand), and the remarks of Senator Tate a moment ago reflected very much the attitude of the Minister. I still have some difficulty with that attitude because if the requirements for the attainment of financial assistance through the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commercial Development Corporation (ATSICDC) will be as restricted as the Bill now defines them, one must ask: Why do these Aboriginal people not simply go to a bank or one of the normal finance institutions to obtain a loan? The answer that the Minister gave me when I discussed this matter with him was that some people with perfectly good commercial proposals will not get loans from banks simply because they are Aboriginal. If that were the case, the anti-discrimination legislation could deal with that.

There is a need for and a desirability in accepting some definition of economic viability and the purposes and direction of loans which is less than the very tough criteria that banks and normal commercial enterprises might apply. Indeed, subclause 17 (3) of the Bill states:
The Commission shall not exercise its powers . . . in relation to a business enterprise unless it is satisfied that the enterprise is likely to become, or continue to be, commercially successful.

The Bill covering the interim stages of the Aboriginal Economic Development Corporation contained essentially the same words, and they would be more appropriate words to apply. I point out to the Government that the Australian Industry Development Corporation (AIDC) is a body which provides financial assistance for those proposals which would not normally attract finance but which, it is judged, eventually will become economically viable. So there is a criterion which is less fully financially stringent which this Bill attempts to apply to proposals coming from Aboriginal people to ATSICDC. It is worth while remarking that since 1979 the body I have just referred to, the AIDC, has become a very economically profitable body, to the extent that recently the Government sold 3 per cent of it to private interests. There seems to be no danger that in setting up these lesser criteria the ATSICDC would necessarily fail as a financial institution. As I indicated this morning, having debated this matter with the Minister on a number of occasions and having got absolutely nowhere, one must make a judgment as to whether this Bill in its present form is sufficiently satisfactory to support.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am sure he would not refuse it on the basis of this. I don't believe it.

—I put on the record that it is my private view that a hidden agenda is involved in this. I do not think I am saying anything that the Opposition would disagree with-that is, in these types of amendments and in the recommendations of the Senate Select Committee the Minister saw the success of an alternative proposal put by the ADC. He was simply not prepared to countenance that a group that he had disparaged, and indeed eventually had sacked, should have any success at all with an alternative proposal. It seems to me that that is the hidden agenda behind this. I believe there is merit in broadening the terms of operation of the ATSICDC to encompass all those economic development functions which, by definition, were either likely to become or continue to be commercially successful. I believe that is the hidden agenda behind the Minister's intransigence. On balance, I must say that it is better to see the Bill in its present form adopted than to proceed with amendments which may doom the Bill. I say that very reluctantly because, as Senator Peter Baume quite rightly points out, these are important considerations. I think that the Minister is being intransigent and foolish in this matter. He is not providing the best structure. It is an adequate structure, but not the best structure that could be provided.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is quite correct that we are merely attempting to move one clause from one part of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission Bill to another. We are attempting to move clause 17, where it relates to ATSIC, to a new clause 149a which relates to the Development Commission. I will now respond to what Senator Coulter said. Our duty in this Committee is quite clear: it is to pursue the merit of the matter, to examine the clauses of the Bill and to produce the best Bill possible. Senator Coulter has not in any way cast doubt upon the fact that the merit of the matter lies with moving the clause from point A to point B.

SPEECH.PARA: I will not go over those arguments again. If the Senate operated by trying to read the mind of a Minister, we would never amend anything in this place; we would not pursue anything. I do not believe for one minute that moving clause 17 out and putting it in the Aboriginal Development Commission Amendment Bill as clause 149a would make the Minister refuse to see his beloved child ATSIC come to fruition. It would merely mean that he would be the sire of a better product. If the honourable senator is saying to the Committee, `I think you are right. I think there is merit in the argument. It is what I suggested but I am not going to vote for it because I do not think the Minister will accept it', that is not in keeping with what the Senate is about.

TALK.START.PARA: —He can make that decision when it comes back. It can go down there. If the Minister knocks it back he can then make a decision.

—That is the second arm of the argument-that if in the end it were unacceptable to the Minister we would have another chance. I freely acknowledge that if at that stage Senator Coulter then said that the alternative for him was not to accept it-to let it go through in an imperfect form-I would have a lot more sympathy. I have no sympathy with the argument that, having tried to read the mind of the Minister, Senator Coulter has decided that he will vote against something that he believes has merit.

SPEECH.PARA: I know what people say about the Australian Democrats. I do my best not to believe it. But it is moments like this which drive me to despair. This is an argument based on the merit of the matter. In the last five minutes Senator Coulter has told us where the merit lies: it lies with the Opposition amendment. I suggest that if the amendment is agreed to, the Minister will accept it-not very happily. I make the point that this Parliament controls Ministers; Ministers are not here to control the Parliament.

It is the old story about the Executive and the Parliament. We have to determine who is in charge. If I accept what Senator Coulter says, we might as well not have had the Glorious Revolution 300 years ago because we would be merely acknowledging again the superior authority of the Crown and the Executive. It will not do. If the amendment has merit, Senator Coulter should vote for it. Senator Boswell is correct: if it then transpired-and it will not-that the Minister sent the Bill back and said, `I will not accept it without amendment' I would listen to Senator Coulter's argument. But he has not put the Minister to the test. Of course the Minister has tried to bluff the honourable senator. What Minister worth his salt would not? Senator Coulter would be a great person to play poker against!

TALK.START.PARA: —You are getting very personal.

—Senator Tate is absolutely correct; I will stop doing that. But I say that if the amendment has merit it is the duty of this Committee to vote for it because there will be another chance to look at the politics, if that is necessary. I commend and press the amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the package of amendments moved by Senator Peter Baume. I am attracted to his initial statements on this area which drew attention to the alternative strategy in an Aboriginal self-management paper that was prepared on behalf of the Aboriginal Development Commission (ADC) and presented to the Senate Select Committee on the Administration of Aboriginal Affairs. Very strong attention was drawn to the need-and, I gather, at that particular time this also attracted Senator Coulter's support-for the concepts that were put out in that particular paper.

SPEECH.PARA: I would also like to remind the Committee that we have had the advantage on several occasions this year of considering the very important reports of the Auditor-General into the activities of the ADC. Amongst a number of reports that were commissioned by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the Government into the Aboriginal affairs portfolio was the Special Audit Report of the Auditor-General. The Auditor-General tabled his first report-a very significant and comprehensive report-on 9 March. That report raised many issues in respect of the way in which things should happen. It raised a number of fears that we have looked at as to the development corporation aspects of ATSIC. We must be mindful that the same problems will not arise again.

I also remind the Committee that yesterday the Auditor-General tabled a further report which was a follow-up to the report of 9 March. In the report tabled yesterday the Auditor-General draws our attention to a number of very significant points. For example, in the summary the report states:
. . . the ADC has not carried out all necessary follow-up action or improved procedures on all recent projects.
I remind the Committee that that comment has been made since the report of 9 March. The report continues:

They are further examples of poor administration of ADC's enterprise finance projects of the kind detailed in the Special Audit Report. There was no positive indication from ADC that it intended to improve its administration and to pay more attention to the requirements of the ADC Act.
In his introductory remarks on page 2 of the same report, the Auditor-General says:

1.6 As indicated in the report some matters raised in the audit have not been adequately addressed by ADC or were still awaiting a response by ADC. AAO considered that, in the light of the time given to the ADC for reply, further delay in reporting was unwarranted.

1.7 Most of the matters raised in this report concern ADC. Like the Special Audit Report, this report indicates that, in its program to finance Aboriginal enterprises, ADC must have proper regard to the requirements in the ADC Act, particularly the requirements that finance is to be provided only for the purpose of enabling Aboriginals to engage in business enterprise and that ADC must satisfy itself that particular Aboriginals are capable of engaging in the enterprise. Compliance with the latter requirement helps to protect public money from being spent on unsuccessful enterprises and helps to avoid the disappointment that arises from such enterprises.

1.8 The report also indicates a need for ADC to clarify its objectives with each project that it finances and to improve administrative procedures for ensuring that funds are applied only for approved purposes. Programs for economic development are not to be confused with social welfare programs.
I think this bears out very much the fears and the concerns that Senator Peter Baume has drawn to our attention and highlights the attention that we have to give to this package of amendments.

As we are dealing with enterprise loans and grants for the purposes of Aboriginal people, we must also be mindful of the other groups in the community that make grants available for Aboriginal enterprise. Whilst the development corporation component of ATSIC will be very important, Aboriginal people will be able to obtain grants for their own purposes by various other means. One of those sources of funds, particularly for Aboriginals in the Northern Territory, is the Aboriginal Benefits Trust Account into which is paid mining royalties from the very significant mining revenues of the Northern Territory. Almost $145m has been collected and disbursed in the last 10 years. Honourable senators may have heard me refer in this place in the last few days to the July 1989 report of Greg Crough from the Economic and Social Policy Research Unit of the University of Sydney. The comments in that report are very concerning because, whilst significant amounts of money have been passed through that trust account for loans, grants and enterprise, a formula also provides for the administration of land councils. The Minister has used his discretion on a number of occasions--

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Temporary Chairman, I take a point of order. I really fail to see how, when we are discussing the way in which the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commercial Development Corporation might have its charter further extended to enable it to make concessional loans to business enterprises, the question of the trust funds making moneys available for land councils is relevant. I think I know what Senator Tambling wants to do. If he wants to do it he should do it and allow us to get on with the relevant discussion on these clauses; otherwise we will spend a considerable amount of time on something which, by any standard, is irrelevant to the clause.

—The point I was wishing to make is that the Aboriginal Benefits Trust Account not only gives money for the administration of land councils but also makes commercial grants available for the use of Aboriginal people. The Crough report that I was referring to states in part:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the ABTA is in a state of serious crisis.
The financial position of the ABTA is very serious indeed. In the past year there has been a rapid decline in the level of these funds.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Temporary Chairman, I take a point of order. I must insist that this is becoming a debate about the ABTA. I understand the concerns of honourable senators about it; I understand that it is to be the subject of extended discussion at the Estimates Committee. I have given Senator Tambling a guarantee that I will have the ministerial delegate available for those discussions-at great inconvenience, as I have to try to get him down from the Northern Territory. I really think that it is an abuse of this Committee's time, when we are looking at these clauses, to have an extended description of the malaise or the difficulties that are besetting the ABTA. I ask you to confine the debate to the relevant discussion of the extension of the charter of the Development Corporation, as sought by Senator Baume's amendment.

—Mr Temporary Chairman, on the point of order: the Committee is considering the Bill as a whole. In the event that the point of order were upheld it would be quite competent for Senator Tambling to rise, as soon as the amendments were disposed of, and carry on with the discussion on the ABTA.
—It still has to be relevant to a clause.

—I referred to it on Wednesday at some length. No point of order was taken at that stage. It may suit the convenience of the Committee to get it out of the way now and then deal with the amendments that are before us.
—I bring my comments to conclusion. I seek leave of the Committee to table a copy of the report by Greg Crough on the Aboriginal Benefits Trust Account.
