SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition has moved a set of amendments which, if passed, will guarantee that the enterprise loans and grants function is transferred to the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commercial Development Corporation. The Senate Select Committee on the Administration of Aboriginal Affairs made this recommendation in its report and it was backed by Senator Coulter in the press release referred to by Senator Peter Baume. If these amendments are not carried, when ATSIC receives applications for money for whatever, it will come down to a competition between welfare and development. When we come down to the bottom line I am afraid that welfare will always win. The coalition believes that we should give these people a fishing line rather than a fish. A fishing line would help them to put fish on the dinner plate every night whereas a fish would be a welfare grant. That is our concern. We want Aboriginals to develop their own businesses and enterprises. We want Aboriginals to take pride in what they are doing rather than develop a welfare mentality, looking for sit-down money, hand-outs and dole money. I know that Senator Peter Baume will support me when I say that we believe we must encourage businesses, development, art and so on. This will not happen unless these amendments are carried. If two proposals are put to ATSIC, one for development and one for welfare, my experience is that the welfare proposal will get the green light.

SPEECH.PARA: I understand Senator Baume's frustration; he is a very level-headed, even-tempered man but I noted a tone of desperation creeping into his voice. Senator Baume knows what I am saying is true, Senator Coulter knows it and, if Senator Tate were not riding under ministerial instructions, he would be prepared to admit it. We went through the stages of having a committee, travelling right round Australia, finding out what is needed in ATSIC, and trying to amend a Bill to get the best benefits for Aboriginal people. Now Senator Coulter comes in here and says, `I know that everything you say is right. We should do it, but I am not game to say so because the Minister might knock back the Bill'. I put it to Senator Coulter that he is not fulfilling the role that he was elected to fulfil. His role, in holding the balance of power, is to `keep the bastards honest', as one of his former leaders once said. But he is not keeping anyone honest, least of all himself. He cannot be true even to himself. If he believes that something is right, is in the best interests of Aboriginal people and is the way in which Aboriginal people will be able to control their own businesses and get away from this welfare mentality, for goodness sake, why will he not acknowledge that and place his vote where his mouth is? He is like the preacher who gets up before the congregation every Sunday and says, `Do what I tell you but don't do what I am doing'. Senator Coulter is not setting any example at all. His attitude is very wishy-washy and I cannot understand it. He is the one who put out the press release; he is the one who called for these amendments; and he is the one who went into the Senate Select Committee and demanded these things. I congratulate him for understanding the need for this measure, but I condemn him for his lack of courage to stand up for what he believes in.

That is a shocking indictment of the Australian Democrats. It is not as though Senator Coulter does not have the intellect to understand what is needed; he understands what is needed but he does not have the courage of his convictions. I do not know what Senator Coulter thinks Mr Hand will do to him; I do not know what power Mr Hand has over Senator Coulter-there is none that I have seen. The Senate Select Committee spent months going around all these places and it was a complete fiasco. Senator Coulter comes back here and says, `I really know that you are right but I do not have the courage to stand up and put my point of view. I go to water like a wet sponge'. Surely the people who cast their votes for the Democrats would expect that at least you would stand up for what you believe is right. What is the point of you coming here--

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Boswell, please address your remarks through the Chair.

—I am sorry, Mr Temporary Chairman. I too am getting frustrated; I must control myself. What is the point of Senator Coulter standing up in here and arguing a case, supporting the Opposition and then saying that he does not have the courage to go ahead with it because the Minister might do something to him? I ask him to reconsider his position. If he thinks something is right he should stand up for it. If he does not think it is right he should vote against it. If he does not have the courage to take either position, he should reconsider his position in the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have lived with this legislation, as several other senators in this place have, since December 1987. I have served on the Senate Select Committee on the Administration of Aboriginal Affairs. I have visited a number of Aboriginal communities. As Senator Boswell and Senator Peter Baume have both said, I have stated my position. I have not tried to hide it. I could equally as well, if I chose to be devious, mount an argument for the Government's position on this. I have chosen not to do that. My aim is to get the best that is obtainable for Aboriginal people out of a package which includes certain clauses that we are now debating. I am not reading the Minister's mind in this matter, nor has the Minister any hold over me or made any threats against me. I have had hours and hours of discussions with the Minister. I see that two of the Minister's advisers are in the chamber. They know that I have had many hours of discussion with the Minister on this subject. I know how far the Minister can be pushed on this matter without the possibility of damaging this legislation. I am in a very difficult position. I acknowledge that I would like to see certain changes in this legislation but I am not prepared to see this legislation fail by reason of pushing those changes too hard.

SPEECH.PARA: In stating the position I am expressing the hope that the Minister and the Government will find it necessary to modify this legislation as it goes forward. At this stage I am not prepared to doom this legislation on the grounds of putting into place amendments which I believe the Government would find totally unacceptable. Senator Baume has made the point that the legislation could come back. I ask him to reflect on the fact that we are facing an election some time within the next six to nine months. We have a very heavy legislative program. This legislation has already been held up for a very long period. That is a consideration which must weigh with responsible senators who, on balance, believe that this legislation is in the best interests of Aboriginal people. That is the judgment that I have made. That is the judgment that I have clearly stated on a number of occasions in the course of this debate. In the light of that I do not see it as being at all inconsistent on one particular clause to state a position and then say that I am not prepared to go to the point of actually voting on an amendment.

The matter of the separation of welfare and economic development functions is an important issue. I would like to see those functions further separated. I believe there was substantial evidence before the House of Representatives committee of inquiry into the Aboriginal Development Commission to support that position. However, I do not believe at this stage-in light of many hours of discussion with the Minister-that that position can be pushed through at this stage. I do not think that that is in any sense dishonest. I am being completely open with my philosophical position and stating precisely why I am taking the course of action that I intend to take. I do not believe that that is in any way letting down the Australian Democrats or anybody else. I am attempting to get the very best for Aboriginal people in the light of the package which is before us.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I appreciate Senator Coulter's difficulty. I understand his position. I hope that I have understood it correctly to mean that he would vote for this group of amendments if he thought it would not doom the package. His concern is that it may doom the package. He thinks it may doom the package-let me see whether I understood it correctly-because the Bills may not come back to this place as other parliamentary business would prevent that happening, or that the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Hand) would then say that this amendment is so unacceptable that, given the choice between having his ATSIC package with the desirable amendment, to which Senator Coulter is committed in an intellectual sense, and doing without the legislation, the Minister would say he would do without the legislation. I must say that I have been trying to roll that argument around my head. I simply cannot believe it.

SPEECH.PARA: We are going to test the Australian Democrats on this group of amendments. We have also spoken to the Office of Parliamentary Counsel this morning. We are going to test the Australian Democrats on the other matter about which they have spoken long and publicly; that is, the matter we discussed this morning concerning electoral rolls. I would listen to the argument that the honourable senator has just put to the Committee concerning electoral rolls, but on this other matter I just wonder. If the Bill went back to the House of Representatives with this amendment I believe the Minister would accept the Bill as amended for one of two reasons: either he would accept it because this amendment, like many other amendments which have been included at the end of the day, is acceptable-I remind the Committee that the three Bills have had 98 or 99 amendments agreed to in this place-or--

TALK.START.PARA: —All you have to do is ask him would he jettison the package if this amendment went through.

—Senator Harradine is quite right. Suppose the Minister was then told by his colleagues that it is not going to get another run around, that there is no parliamentary time. The Minister would then be faced with two options: one is to say that he will not accept this amendment which moves clause 17 across from ATSIC to the Development Commission; the other is to say that he will accept it and that he is not happy about it. I say to Senator Coulter that I think his argument to the Committee that he would doom the legislation by voting for the amendment simply does not hold up. If this amendment went in the legislation would proceed. You, Mr Temporary Chairman, and Senator Coulter know that the Opposition is opposed to the legislation. We remain opposed to it. That is no secret either. But I cannot believe that the amendments, if accepted, would doom the legislation. I have tested them against the very proposition Senator Coulter has put. Mr Hand would know very quickly whether it was going to have a chance to come back here for another look as the procedures allow or if the pressure of parliamentary business would prevent that happening.
—It would have to come back anyhow.

—It may not have to. If all our amendments were accepted in the other place that would be the end of it. We would then have the Bill in an agreed form. If that were the choice facing Minister Hand he would accept the legislation. I do not believe that anyone can accept that this would be of sufficient magnitude to make him say he would rather have no legislation at all. I appreciate the dilemma in which Senator Coulter finds himself, but he is just wrong in the conclusion that he has drawn. We do press the amendments.

SPEECH.PARA: Question put:
That the amendments (Senator Peter Baume's) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (2) Page 69 and 70, clause 183, line 20 (page 69) to line 8 (page 70), leave out the clause.
(3) Page 70, clause 184, lines 14 and 15, leave out ``; and (b) provision for income tax''.
(4) Page 70, clause 187, lines 31 to 35, leave out the clause, insert the following clause:
Exemption from taxation
``187. The Corporation is not subject to taxation under any law of the Commonwealth or of a State or Territory.''.

The Opposition in particular will recall that the Aboriginal Development Commission (ADC) was an instrument of its creation, that a capital account was created clearly in recognition of prior occupation and dispossession by Aboriginal people and that that capital account was not subject to taxation for that very good reason. It was not income; it was a compensatory sum paid to the ADC. Under this legislation, that capital account is to be taken over by the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commercial Development Corporation (ATSICDC). It certainly seems to the Australian Democrats, and indeed the Senate Select Committee on the Administration of Aboriginal Affairs recommended it, that the practice of not paying tax on that capital account should continue. It is therefore appropriate that amendments Nos 2, 3 and 4 have been moved by the Democrats.
Clause 183, on pages 69 and 70 of the Bill, sets up the whole mechanism for the payment of dividend to the Commonwealth. Clause 817, on page 70 of the Bill, deals with the liability to taxation.

We are suggesting there that an alternative clause be written in to the effect that the Corporation will not be subject to taxation under any law of the Commonwealth or of a State or Territory. In discussing this matter also with the Minister, he quite correctly pointed out that it would be possible to achieve the same objective as the requirement not to pay taxation by simply putting less money into the capital account. We see that that logically follows. However, it is certainly far more honest for the Government to put less money into the capital account than it is to put more money into it and then claw some back by way of taxation. For that reason, while the end result might be the same, it is far more honest and open for that capital account to be seen for what it is-a compensation account. Therefore, it should not be subject to taxation.

As I understand the Minister's position on this point, he is personally favourable to the suggestion but has had some difficulty with the more hard-nosed people in his own Party such as Senator Walsh and the Treasurer (Mr Keating). Nonetheless, I have the feeling that as the end financial result of these amendments may be no different from what is in the present Bill, it would certainly be a great deal more honest. I commend these amendments to the Committee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government rejects these amendments on the basis that in establishing the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commercial Development Corporation (ATSICDC)-and I think it has been reinforced by the last vote-it intends that this Corporation act as a commercial business enterprise, that it should operate according to sound business principles and that it be governed by the usual rules that apply to such business enterprises. The policy guidelines for Commonwealth statutory authorities and government business enterprises issued in October 1987 make it clear that when an enterprise, consistent with its statutory obligations, is able to generate a financial surplus after meeting all costs and interest charges, appropriate dividends will be paid to the Commonwealth unless the enterprise can demonstrate that there are compelling reasons for its retaining the whole of that surplus.

SPEECH.PARA: We know that under the Bill itself there is a holiday from the payment of dividends until 1993-94, which allows it to get under way and to reinvest such surpluses as it is able to generate in making further provision for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander business enterprises. However, as a matter of ensuring that the ATSICDC is treated in the same way as other Commonwealth creations in the business commercial area, it is important that it pay taxes and dividends as those other organisations do.

Senator Coulter said something about compensation, that the capital fund could be regarded as compensation and, therefore, taxation should not be paid on the way in which it is successfully utilised in the community where it provides loans to business enterprises in a businesslike and commercial way. If I have a car accident and am compensated, and if I receive $100,000 and use that $100,000 to generate income, of course I pay tax on that income. I do not quite see how the fact that the capital fund could in a sense be regarded as compensation necessarily leads to the argument that taxation should not be paid in respect of the successful operation of the enterprise using that capital fund, whatever the motive was in making the capital fund available initially. The Government cannot accept these amendments. I believe that the fully commercial operation of the Corporation having been strengthened in the last vote only adds force to the Government's rejection of the proposed amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government forgets history. The Aboriginal Development Commission (ADC) Act is where we have to go to find out what the purposes of the Parliament were. Section 3 of the ADC Act, which relates to the purpose of the ADC, states:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . to further the economic and social development of people of the Aboriginal race of Australia and people who are descendants of indigenous inhabitants of the Torres Strait Islands and, in particular, (as a recognition of past dispossession and dispersal of such people) to establish a Capital Account with the object of promoting their development, self-management and self-sufficiency.

The ADC capital fund is not in any way equivalent to the funds which may be available to a commercial organisation. It is absolutely wrong for the Government to try to so present it. If the Government wishes to present the ATSICDC as just another commercial organisation, it follows that the Government is moving away from the commitment that was made in the ADC Act that the capital fund was being established to take account, by way of compensation, for past dispossession and dispersal. That is precisely the point that Senator Coulter is making. The ADC capital fund is not like the funds of any other commercial organisations. The history of its development makes that point. Many Aboriginal people put it to the Senate Select Committee on the Administration of Aboriginal Affairs that to make a dividend payable or to make the fund taxable is in effect taking back from the Aboriginal people what was given in recognition of past dispersal and dispossession. Those comments appear in the report of the Senate Select Committee at paragraphs 3.74 to 3.78.

I have to say that had the Australian Democrats not moved these amendments we had amendments ready in precisely the same form to move. As we believe that these amendments are necessary, we will, of course, support them. The requirement on ATSICDC to pay a dividend presumably applies to its after-tax earnings. The earnings on the capital of $60m-if that is what its capital is by 1992, and that is what is promised-would be about $9m or, if we allow for a bit of administration, $8m, and tax, at 39 per cent, would leave about $5.5m. Out of that a dividend has to be found, so not much would be left for investment in the objective of Aboriginal self-sufficiency.

Senator Coulter made clear his concerns about this matter in a letter he sent recently to Aboriginal communities. He made it clear that he understands the purposes behind the original creation of the ADC capital fund. The Opposition agrees with him. The Labor Government has given no money at all to the capital fund since it took office-not a penny. The last time any contribution was made, I think, was by my successor in the portfolio, Mr Wilson, in 1982-83. The Government now says that it is offering $40m to the capital fund. It is interesting to note what the Government says. I remind the Committee that the capital fund now stands at $20m. The document, Foundations for the Future, states:

The Act will provide that the AEDC's capital base shall be $60 million, of which $40 million (including the $20 million in assets of the ADC's Capital Fund) would be paid on commencement, with the remainder in equal instalments in 1989-90 and 1990-91.
The same sort of thing was said by the Minister in the second reading speech. He said:

The Corporation's capital base will comprise the $20m which has been allocated to the Capital Fund of the ADC since its establishment plus an extra $40m to be allocated over this and the next three years. As a consequence, the Corporation will have a very significant capital base.

I have looked at the estimates for the current financial year, 1989-90. There is no money-not a penny-for the capital fund. We are told that $40m will be provided over five years but there is none this year-not a penny. Not only that, but the Government is now asking us to make that money taxable and subject to dividend. No way! The Government is putting no money in this year. It is not a question of putting less money in; it cannot put in less than nothing.

TALK.START.PARA: —How much will it pull out in tax?

—The Government may provide a tax holiday for several years but in the longer run Aboriginal and Islander people will be worse off if these provisions are allowed to stand. The Aboriginal Development Commission capital fund is a special fund for reasons which were made clear when the ADC was established. The fund is not subject to tax or dividend. It is bad enough that ATSIC has been created and that it will subsume the ADC and that the ADC capital fund is to be subsumed. But we will not be party to the Aboriginal people being cheated in this way and we will support the amendments moved by the Australian Democrats.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Justice (Senator Tate) drew an analogy between the position of Aboriginal people and someone involved in a motor vehicle accident being compensated and then earning money on the compensation. If the Aboriginal people had been fully compensated for their dispossession, they may have been paid many trillions of dollars. The correct analogy would be with Senator Tate's being compensated to the tune of $500,000 but getting $10,000 as a down payment and then being asked to pay tax on that $10,000 while he waited for the remainder. That would be quite unconscionable.

SPEECH.PARA: I am not convinced, as Senator Baume has said, that necessarily the Aboriginal people will get more because of these amendments. However, I make the claim that it will be far more honest if the Government pays money into the capital account. I reflect on what Senator Baume said. I forgot to mention earlier that the Government has not put money into this capital account at all since 1983.

TALK.START.PARA: —Not a penny.
—Not a dollar; Senator Baume is talking in the old currency. No money has gone into this capital account.
—Not a farthing.

—Senator Baume is really showing his age. For the Government then to put money in and claw some back by way of dividends and taxation is quite without conscience, bearing in mind the purpose for which this fund was created. It may be that the Government gets away with putting less money in but that is a far more honest way for it to go.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALK.START.PARA: -I am glad to be able to support the Australian Democrats' amendment. It seems to me totally dishonest for a government not to have subscribed any money to the Aboriginal Development Commission (ADC) fund since it has come to office and then to have the audacity to demand tax on the fund. I do not see how the Minister for Justice (Senator Tate) can defend that position. If I could offer him a little advice, I would say that when he is put in an embarrassing position he should sit there, say nothing and get on to the next point. It is very hard to defend the indefensible even for a former law dean of the University of Tasmania. That stretches anyone's ability, even that of the most brilliant lawyer-and I include Senator Tate in that category. To try to push that line is just not on.

SPEECH.PARA: It is passing strange-and I want to put this on record-that when the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Hand) cannot roll Cabinet or get his own way in Cabinet he sends the Australian Democrats out to rat on his own Cabinet mates. He says to the Democrats, `Look, I agree with you fully. I support you. You go out and plunge the knife right between the shoulder blades of my Cabinet colleagues'. On the other hand, Minister Hand will not give the green light to anything that Senator Coulter wants to do; there seems to be a veto on the Democrats.

I am finding it very strange to understand this debate. Senator Coulter says that the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs has given him his blessing, albeit under the table, not to support the Government line. I am sure that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) would be terribly disappointed in Mr Hand for taking that attitude. Under the Westminster system of Cabinet government, solidarity demands that all Ministers are united. There seems to be some element of this missing in the Hawke Ministry.

I say again that if it is good enough for Senator Coulter to do what Mr Hand wants when he wants to do it and when he supports it, I hope that when we come to the Senate amendments and Senator Coulter has a position that differs from that of the Minister and the Government, the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs will have the integrity to support the Democrats' position.
Amendments agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (76) Page 59, clause 143, lines 20 to 24, leave out the clause, insert the following clause:
Purposes of Corporation
``143. The Corporation is established:
(a) to assist and enhance Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander self-management and economic self-sufficiency; and

(b) to advance the commercial and economic interests of Aboriginal persons and Torres Strait Islanders by accumulating and using a substantial capital asset for the benefit of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples.''.
(77) Page 59, clause 144, before paragraph (a) insert the following paragraph:
``(aa) to promote and encourage Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander self-management and economic self-sufficiency;''.

These amendments go to the purposes of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commercial Development Corporation. Amendment No. 76 seeks to insert a clause in place of clause 143 which appears at page 59. Clause 143 as it appears concerns the purposes of the Corporation. The clause which we seek to put in its place says:
143. The Corporation is established:
(a) to assist and enhance Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander self-management and economic self-sufficiency; and

(b) to advance the commercial and economic interests of Aboriginal persons and Torres Strait Islanders by accumulating and using a substantial capital asset for the benefit of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples.

The purposes clause, of course, interprets all the others. Thus it is important to make clear that self-management and self-sufficiency for Aboriginal people are an important purpose of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission Bill 1989. That is what this amendment seeks to do. It is important to ensure that there is a clear distinction known and understood between self-management and self-determination. I refer members of the Committee who might be unaware of that distinction to an excellent piece of writing by Senator Chaney in the last year or so. He is a great champion of Aboriginal people and has been for most of his life. He points out correctly that the word `self-determination' has a particular meaning at international law and that it is important to draw the distinction between self-management and self-determination. We are not developing a two-nation concept here. We are trying to be constructive rather than divisive. We think that the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commercial Development Corporation should address the very serious task of pursuing Aboriginal self-management. The amendment which we have moved seeks to make that clear.

Amendment No. 77 seeks to insert paragraph (aa) before subclause (a) in clause 44 to say that one of the functions of the Corporation is to promote and encourage Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander self-management and economic self-sufficiency. Under the amendment proposed to clause 143, self-management would become a purpose of the Commercial Development Corporation. Its importance is such that its promotion and encouragement, besides being a purpose, should also be a function of the Corporation. In a sense, it is consequential upon the other amendment. We have had an indication from the Minister that the Government might find these two amendments acceptable. Therefore, I will not speak further on them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government has indicated its acceptance of amendments Nos 76 and 77. As far as amendment No. 77 is concerned, it has been suggested, and I wonder whether Senator Peter Baume can accommodate this request, that clause 144 should read:

SPEECH.PARA: The Corporation has the following functions:
(a) to engage in commercial activities; to promote and encourage Aboriginals and Torres Strait Islanders' self-management and economic self-sufficiency.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to vary the amendment to insert the words `(aa) to promote and encourage Aboriginals and Torres Strait Islander self-management and economic self-sufficiency;' as a new subclause between existing subclauses (a) and (b) in clause 144. In other words, I am seeking to meet the request of the Minister in this matter.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
Amendments, as amended, agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (78) Page 60, subclause 147 (2), lines 23 to 25, leave out the subsubclause, insert the following subclause:
``(2) The Corporation shall give a copy of the corporate plan to the Minister and may also give to the Minister a copy of any written comments by the Commission about the corporate plan.''.
(79) Page 60, subclause 147 (3), line 26, leave out ``after consulting with the Commission,''.
(80) Page 60, after subclause 147 (3), add the following new subclauses:
``(4) The Minister shall cause a copy of the corporate plan to be laid before each House of the Parliament within 15 sitting days of that House after receipt by the Minister.
``(5) The Minister shall cause a copy of any notice given under subsection (3) to be laid before each House of the Parliament within 15 sitting days of that House after it is given.''.

These amendments go to consideration of the corporate plan by the Minister and related matters. Amendment No. 78 seeks to amend clause 147, at page 60, to leave out subclause (2) and insert a new subclause as follows:
The corporation shall give a copy of the corporate plan to the Minister and may also give to the Minister a copy of any written comments by the Commission about the corporate plan.

The Opposition believes that the line of authority for the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commercial Development Corporation should go directly from the Minister to the Corporation and not through the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission (ATSIC). We are seeking in this group of amendments to ensure that that is the case. Amendment No. 79 is also an amendment to clause 147 on page 60, at line 26, to leave out the words, `after consulting with the Commission'. It would then read:
The Minister may, by notice in writing to the Corporation Board, request the Corporation Board . . .

That merely means that the Minister can have a direct working relationship with the Commercial Development Corporation. We think that is more appropriate. We do not think it should be completely subservient to ATSIC for reasons which we set out during the second reading debate and in various other amendments. The third amendment, No. 80, also amends clause 147. It seeks to add two more subclauses at the end of the clause. Subclause (4) reads:
The Minister shall cause a copy of the corporate plan to be laid before each House of the Parliament within 15 sitting days of that House after receipt by the Minister.
Subclause (5) reads:
The Minister shall cause a copy of any notice given under subsection (3)-
which provides for the giving of notices-
to be laid before each House of the Parliament within 15 sitting days of that House after it is given.

We think that ATSIC has enough to do without wanting to interfere in the activities of the Development Corporation. We also think that the commissioners of ATSIC are likely to be elected for reasons which would not include the possession of business or financial skills; it would be more of a political election. Their qualifications would be in local political and community life. Therefore, it is unlikely that they would be ideally qualified to pass judgment on the activities of the Development Corporation. We think that provision for tabling the corporate plan and notices to be given by the Minister should ensure that some oversight is exercised by Parliament as to whether there is or is not undue ministerial interference. If these matters were laid before the Parliament it would at least provide some stimulus for any member of parliament, who thought there was undue interference by the Minister, to take action if he wished to do so. I believe that those three amendments are acceptable to the Government and, accordingly, I will not debate them at any great length.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government accepts amendments Nos. 78, 79 and 80.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendments agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (81) Page 60, clause 148, lines 29 to 31, leave out the clause, insert the following clause:
Directions by Minister
``148. (1) The Corporation shall perform its functions and exercise its powers in accordance with such general directions as are given to it by the Minister in writing.

``(2) Subsection (1) does not empower the Minister to give directions relating to the content of any advice or information that may be given by the Corporation to a Minister, Department or authority of the Commonwealth or of a State or Territory.

``(3) Subject to subsection (4), the Minister shall cause a copy of any direction given by the Minister under subsection (1) to be laid before each House of the Parliament within 15 sitting days of that House after that direction was given.
``(4) A copy of a direction laid before the Parliament in accordance with subsection (3) shall not disclose:
(a) any matter the disclosure of which in that manner would be inconsistent with the views or sensitivities of relevant Aboriginal persons or Torres Strait Islanders; or
(b) any confidential commercial information given to the Corporation.''.

This amendment seeks to amend clause 148 of the Bill, which appears at page 60, by leaving out that clause and inserting a new clause. Clause 148 as it appears in the Bill is very brief and deals with the powers of the Minister. We seek to replace it with more detailed instructions which might cover the giving of directions by the Minister. Subclause (1) of our amendment reads:
The Corporation shall perform its functions and exercise its powers in accordance with such general directions as are given to it by the Minister in writing.

We have clearly drawn upon our experience with the Aboriginal Development Commission and other relevant experience in drawing up this amendment. In subclause (2) we suggest that subclause (1) should not empower the Minister to give directions relating to the content of any advice or information that may be given by the Corporation to a Minister, department or authority of the Commonwealth or of a State or Territory.

Those members of the Committee who are familiar with the Aboriginal Development Commission model will know that that is very similar to the limitation on the direction-giving power of the Minister contained in the ADC Act. We suggest that a copy of any direction given by the Minister under subclause (1) should be laid before each House of the Parliament within 15 sitting days of that House after that direction is given, and a copy of any such direction laid before the Parliament shall not disclose any secret, sacred or sensitive matter. We have already discussed that in another place.

The recent experience with both Western Australia Inc. and the Victorian Economic Development Corporation shows the need for close ministerial supervision of and ministerial political accountability for publicly funded venture capital operations. If we have learned nothing else over the last year, we should have learnt that. Those Ministers were in trouble because they simply were not taking an interest in what these organisations were doing. We think the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commercial Development Corporation (ATSICDC) should not be at large in the marketplace without some capacity to receive general directions from the Minister, as was provided under section 11 of the Aboriginal Development Commission Act itself.

In drawing up this amendment we have drawn upon section 11 of the ADC Act. We have drawn up amendment No. 81 in terms of section 11 of the ADC Act and proposed it for the ATSICDC. It will not provide for any detailed ministerial supervision of the activities of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commercial Development Corporation. It will provide only for general directions. It will provide that, if the Minister gives such directions, they must be laid before the Parliament. It provides the protections against the disclosure of secret and sensitive information in the same way as those protections are provided in other sections of the Bill.

It could be alleged that such a power could interfere with Aboriginal self-determination or self-management. In reality, that would not be the case because the Corporation is supposed to be dealing on a strict business basis anyway. I do not see why general instructions could interfere with that. The Corporation Board is intended not to be wholly Aboriginal and we think it will be strengthened by some people with particular commercial expertise. It is not proposed that the Minister could make any particular directions; that is, the Minister could not interfere with any particular matter in the same way as the Minister cannot make particular directions under section 11 of the Aboriginal Development Commission Act.

This is a perfectly simple proposal. The powers proposed for the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commercial Development Corporation are very wide powers. They resemble those of Western Australia Inc. and of the Victorian Economic Development Corporation, to which I have referred. The Corporation, for example, would be at large to invest-with the Treasurer's global but not specific approval-or to make guarantees to any person. That is a very wide power. The Western Australia, and Victorian governments got into trouble because of similar powers applying to similar structures. As the amendment to clause 147 has been accepted, the Minister will be able to direct the Corporation in a general way about the manner in which it exercises its powers under clause 148. So we think there are very good reasons to adopt and accept this proposal to amend clause 148. As I say, we have drawn these words directly from section 11 of the Aboriginal Development Commission Act. They are merely a lift from what has worked successfully for all Aboriginal bodies since 1980. We believe that they belong properly with ATSICDC. I commend the amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —Very briefly, Senator Peter Baume, in saying that he was drawing on the experience of the Aboriginal Development Commission, indicated why this is a consequential amendment on the previous attempt by the Opposition to transfer clause 17 from the jurisdiction of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission (ATSIC) to the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commercial Development Corporation. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALK.START.PARA: -The Senate has been aware of my concern for the Queensland pineapple industry. Last Friday I delivered a speech in the Senate outlining the many problems the pineapple industry faces, under attack as it is from cheap imports flooding our market. I told Senator Bolkus privately of my concerns. Senator Bolkus is the Minister for Consumer Affairs, so I asked him whether he would answer some queries, which he has agreed to do. I am very pleased that I will be able to get some answers from Senator Bolkus on behalf of the industry.

SPEECH.PARA: In my contribution last Friday I stated that the imports were taking up to 21 per cent of the market. They do so for a number of reasons. The packaging that is required for imports needs to have some attention directed to it. The packaging and labelling guidelines that are currently followed by the large retailers who market the cheap imported products as their own home or generic brands cause some concern. A huge volume of imported foodstuffs, including canned pineapples, is being brought into Australia and marketed by the major retailers under their generic brands, such as Home Brand and the Farmland label. In the case of canned pineapple, the only Australian product is canned by Golden Circle in Queensland. Every other can of pineapple sold on the supermarket shelves in Australia is imported. The imported products are cleverly labelled to ensure that the consumer has to search to find the vital details of the country of origin on the label.

On 24 February this year, the Industries Assistance Commission (IAC) released the food and beverages industries interim report on government regulation on packaging and labelling. Some of the recommendations outlined in the report proposed radical changes to the way in which the food that we buy on the supermarket shelves is packaged and labelled. Recommendations 3 and 11, for example, propose that the minimum size for label expressions be at least 1.5 millimetres high. That lettering is just larger than a pinhead. Australian consumers should not have to put on their glasses and squint just to ascertain the country of origin of a food product. Recommendation 10 states that the English language requirement in the food standards code be abolished. I think Senator Bolkus told me privately that the Government would not accept that recommendation. He might be in a position to make a statement on that in the Senate. The IAC already expects the Australian consumer to have very good vision and if the proposal to remove the English language requirement is adopted, the consumer will have to be multilingual as well.

Many of the recommendations by the IAC have yet to be accepted by the Government and that is the reason for my contribution this afternoon. The IAC intends to present a final report later this year. Classification of the country of origin declaration on packaging and labelling has been left until this final report. I now ask the Minister for Consumer Affairs, Senator Bolkus, to ensure that any further steps to review packaging and labelling legislation that may be outlined in the final IAC report take into full consideration the needs of the consumer.

I ask the Minister to provide a guarantee that the consumer is not deceived by a false belief that he or she is purchasing Australian products when he or she is really buying an imported product that is packaged as a generic brand. The Minister can do this in two ways. First, he can ensure that the country of origin of a product is displayed clearly and legibly in a prominent position on the front of the can, together with notes on its contents. The country of origin is currently placed discreetly on the back of the can. Secondly, he can ensure that the print-size recommendation of 1.5 millimetres is reviewed so that all print on cans and packages is able to be read clearly.

I have also been in contact with the Minister's office about my concerns that citric acid is added to imported pineapple products by the overseas processors to improve the taste and quality of the product. It is against Australian health regulations to add this acid without declaring it on the label. However, tests in the United States of America have shown that much of the imported pineapple stock has been boosted in this manner, without the consumer being aware of the additive. I have passed this information on to Senator Bolkus's office for his perusal.

The processors of these products face a catch 22 situation. If they do not boost the citric acid levels, they face the risk of pathogens surviving the cooking process as well as an unacceptably flat taste. If they do use the additional citric acid without the correct labelling, they are unfairly marketing their pineapples against the natural Australian product. The Minister has indicated that he will take note of my concerns. I now ask that he investigate the addition of this acid into the cheap imported pineapple products sold to Australian consumers as generic brands and give his firm commitment to oversee the changes to the labelling and packaging legislation so that it is in the best interests of the consumer.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Boswell for raising this matter and also for the notice he gave me in respect to it. He has raised a real live situation in which government policies can affect people and their consumption habits, and can also affect industry within Australia. He raised a number of issues. I will go to the labelling ones first. The issues he has raised have been very much of priority concern to me over the last few months. One of the earliest things I did in this portfolio was to ensure that there was within Australia a uniform regime to ensure adequate country of origin labelling. Before we worked with the Trade Practices Commission to ensure that we had a standard law across the country in this area, there were a whole host of different requirements throughout the country. This made it difficult not only for manufacturers, producers and so on, but also for the people in Australia to understand what the law was on this matter.

SPEECH.PARA: Now, basically, we are saying-it is a clear principle of the law-that if a product is made overseas it has to be labelled as such, and that labelling has to be accurate; it cannot mislead. For instance, we had a situation in which peanuts were imported into Australia. Because they were salted here and the last part of the process occurred in Australia they could be labelled `product of Australia'. We are now saying that a very essential part of the process has to be carried out in Australia before any product imported into Australia can be marked as being made in Australia.

As Senator Boswell said, the Industries Assistance Commission (IAC) recommended a number of approaches in this area, one of which was this requirement that there be standard 1.5 millimetre high labelling. The Government has decided-and the IAC recommended-that this measure be standard across the board for all products. The Government recognises that there is probably a need for a standard requirement as to the height but it also recognises that in exceptional circumstances there needs to be a major deviation from that. The questions of frozen chickens and poisons are two that come to mind very readily. People need to have larger labelling. But we have not endorsed the recommendation of the standard 1.5 millimetre high labelling. Together with the State Ministers for consumer affairs, with whom I met in Hobart in July, we adopted an approach which said, `Let's have a look at a standard size'. But we all felt that 1.5 millimetres was too small and we are looking at a higher figure. To that extent, Senator Boswell's needs are being accommodated. We have to work this through with State governments and thankfully, on this issue, State governments have been cooperative with us.

Once again, the Government felt that the IAC, when making recommendations about the use of English language, was recommending something that we should not adopt, and which we have not adopted. The only problem is that we really cannot dictate where the labelling should go-whether it should be on the front, back or whatever-especially on round cans. We will insist on the requirement that consumers have adequate, clear and legible information of what is in their food.

I now turn to the second part of Senator Boswell's question-that is, imported pineapples and the addition of citric acid. Basically, the standard that the Government is pursuing here is that if something is added to a product, that should be stated on the label. The problem with imported pineapples is that while citric acid is probably the major acid of pineapples-I think Australian pineapples have a content of about 0.8 per cent of citric acid together with a content of 0.2 per cent of malic acid-the acid occurs naturally in the pineapples. I am informed that the pineapples imported from overseas have citric acid levels as low as 0.3 per cent. As Senator Boswell said, that affects palatability. There may also be a question about the survival of pathogens in products of this particular acid content. So far the problem has been one of detecting. The acid occurs naturally in the pineapple. If we claim that acid has been added to it it would be very hard to prove. An article that Senator Boswell referred to in the Senate related to a detection method in the United States which actually focuses on the added acid and can identify the fact that acid has been added. If that is the case, then under the law that this Government has endorsed that would be legal and we could take action.

The question then is how we can prove that. I have embarked upon two courses of action to ensure that not only Australian consumers get a clear idea of what they are eating but also Australian industry be protected to the extent that every player in the field has to conform with the same laws. As Senator Boswell rightly said to me at one stage: if they are doing this overseas there is no way we can check on what they are doing and what they are putting into the product; so we in Australia have to take measures.

I have asked the Federal Bureau of Consumer Affairs to investigate this matter. It will be contacting the Australian Government Analytical Laboratories and the National Food Processors Association in the United States of America to obtain more data on the naturally occurring citric acid levels of fresh pineapples from various Far Eastern countries. I will also be commissioning the Australian Government Analytical Laboratories to conduct tests on the canned pineapples imported from Far East countries to determine citric acid levels in the processed products. This will enable us to determine whether a significant amount has been added to the pineapples on top of the naturally occurring acid. Following the advice that I get from the Australian Government Analytical Laboratories and the Federal Bureau of Consumer Affairs I will be able to determine whether there has been a breach of the domestic laws of Australia. If a breach is established I will take appropriate action to ensure that in future imported pineapples comply with Australian labelling regulations.

In closing, I mention that the Government quite recently announced a comprehensive program to ensure that food products imported into Australia do conform with the requirements of safety and wholesomeness in Australia. To that extent, I, together with my colleagues Senator Cook, Mr Kerin and Dr Blewett, announced that we would be testing high risk food. We would also have other regimes for medium and low risk food to ensure that the Australian food law standards apply to food coming into Australia at the point of import. As I said, Senator Boswell has raised an important issue. It is one that really tests how the law operates. The measures that the Government will introduce and pursue I am sure will be to the benefit of Australian consumers.
